QueryText: Information Regarding Sowing Time Of Jowar
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding sowing time of Jowar
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Jowar (Sorghum)?
KccAns: I Told The Kisan Sowing Time Of Jowar -: 20 March To 10 April
QueryText_normalized: information regarding sowing time of jowar
Primary Answer (Level0): Jowar is mainly a Kharif crop, but in Southern regions, it has a Rabi season crop. It should be sown early (late September to mid-October) to escape harsh cold during flowering. Use resistant varieties like CSV 216R, Phule Anuradha, Phule Revati – these varieties are bred mainly for certain regions but may perform moderately under irrigated conditions and timely sown. Sowing time of jowar is 2nd fortnight of September (25 Sept–5 Oct) or 1st fortnight of October (1–15 Oct). Jowar is traditionally grown as a Kharif crop, but Rabi cultivation is possible under irrigation.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Haryana and North India, jowar is mainly a Kharif crop, but in Southern India, it has a Rabi season crop, it should be sown early (late September to mid-October) to escape harsh cold during flowering. These varieties are grain sorghum varieties that perform under irrigation—e.g., CSV 216R, CSV 18 R, CSV 22, which are part of the national Rabi package. Sowing time of jowar 2nd fortnight of September (25 Sept- 5 Oct) or 1st fortnight of October (1-15 Oct) jowar is traditionally grown as a Kharif crop, but rabi cultivation is possible under irrigation.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Remove reference to Southern-bred varieties (CSV 216R, Phule Anuradha, Phule Revati), which are not released or recommended for grain production in Haryana.

- Specify the recommended Rabi window (despite being an off-season crop) as the 2nd fortnight of September to 1st fortnight of October.

- Suggest Haryana-approved grain sorghum varieties that perform under irrigation—e.g., CSV 216R, CSV 18 R, CSV 22, which are part of the national Rabi package.

Explain briefly why: to help farmers understand the rationale (escape heat, ensure moisture, achieve grain fill).

Once these changes are made, the answer will align with CCS HAU recommendations and your answer will be good to go to the farmer.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Jowar is mainly a Kharif crop, but in Southern India, it has a Rabi season crop, it should be sown early (late September to mid-October) to escape harsh cold during flowering. These varieties are grain sorghum varieties that perform under irrigation—e.g., CSV 216R, CSV 18 R, CSV 22, which are part of the national Rabi package. Sowing time of jowar 2nd fortnight of September (25 Sept- 5 Oct) or 1st fortnight of October (1-15 Oct) jowar is traditionally grown as a Kharif crop, but rabi cultivation is possible under irrigation.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Jowar is primarily a Kharif crop, with sowing done during the onset of the monsoon (last week of May to mid-July). However, rabi cultivation of jowar is feasible under assured irrigation, using early-maturing grain sorghum varieties such as CSV-216R, CSV-18R, and CSV-22, which are part of the national rabi package. According to ICAR-CRIDA contingency planning, the sowing window for rabi-rainfed sorghum is from the end of September to 20 October, while for rabi-irrigated cultivation it ranges from the end of October to 15 November. Kharif jowar (North India/Haryana): Optimal sowing time — late May to mid-July. Rabi jowar under irrigation: Under irrigation, sowing may extend from late September up to mid-November, depending on water availability and the cropping schedule.

QueryText: Control Of Bacterial Leaf Blight In Guar
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bacterial Leaf Blight in Guar (Cluster bean)?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bacterial Leaf Blight in Guar (Cluster bean)?
KccAns: Spray Of Copper Oxicloride  200Gm 30Gm Streptocycline In 200 Liters Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of bacterial leaf blight in guar
Primary Answer (Level0): To control bacterial leaf blight in Guar crop in Zaid season, favorable conditions (high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall) can lead to its rapid spread. Cultural practices include crop rotation with cereals, legumes, proper irrigation, and seed treatment with Streptocycline 1 g + Copper oxychloride 25 g/l in 10 liters of water (soak seeds for 30 mins). Chemical control includes copper oxychloride 50% WP – 400–500 g/acre in 200 L of water, or Streptocycline + Copper mix (Streptocycline 0.01% + Cu oxychloride 0.25%).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): To control bacterial leaf blight in Guar crop in Zaid season here favorable conditions (high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall) can lead to its rapid spread during the Zaid season they are cultural practices like crop rotation with cereals, legumes, proper irrigation, and Seed treatment with Thiram 3g/kg seed or hot water (56 c for 10 min) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. chemical control Foliar sprays with copper oxychloride 50% WP - 400-500g/acre in 200 L of water, Streptocycline + Copper mix - Streptocycline 0.01% + Cu oxychloride 0.25%.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Guar (Clusterbean) is a Kharif crop in Haryana, sown with the monsoon. The advice must be corrected for the Kharif season.
- The advice must be converted to the standard per-acre format. For example, "spray Copper Oxychloride 50% WP at a rate of 500 grams mixed in 200 litres of water per acre." The answer should also be clearly structured with separate points for "Seed Treatment" and "Foliar Spray."
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): To control bacterial leaf blight in Guar crop in Zaid season here favorable conditions (high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall) can lead to its rapid spread during the Zaid season they are cultural practices like crop rotation with cereals, legumes, proper irrigation, and Seed treatment with Thiram 3g/kg seed or hot water (56 c for 10 min) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. chemical control Foliar sprays with copper oxychloride 50% WP - 400-500g/acre in 200 L of water, Streptocycline + Copper mix - Streptocycline 0.01% + Cu oxychloride 0.25%.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Copper oxychloride dose correct but Streptocycline dose high if stated per litre.
- Spray Cu oxychloride 50% WP @ 500 g/acre + Streptocycline @ 0.5 g/10 L water at first symptom.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Bacterial leaf blight is favored by high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall. To manage the disease, follow Integrated Disease Management (IDM) practices such as crop rotation with cereals (wheat, maize) or non-host legumes, proper irrigation, and seed treatment with Thiram @ 3 g/kg seed or hot water treatment (56 °C for 10 minutes) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. Chemical control: Apply a foliar spray of Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 400–500 g/acre in 200 L of water at the first appearance of symptoms.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): Bacterial leaf blight is favored by high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall. To manage the disease, follow Integrated Disease Management (IDM) practices such as crop rotation with cereals (wheat, maize) or non-host legumes, proper irrigation, and seed treatment with Thiram @ 3 g/kg seed or hot water treatment (56 °C for 10 minutes) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. Chemical control: Apply a foliar spray of Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 400–500 g/acre in 200 L of water at the first appearance of symptoms.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): Bacterial leaf blight is favored by high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall. To manage the disease, follow Integrated Disease Management (IDM) practices such as crop rotation with cereals (wheat, maize) or non-host legumes, proper irrigation, and seed treatment with Thiram @ 3 g/kg seed or hot water treatment (56 °C for 10 minutes) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. Chemical control: Apply a foliar spray of Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 400–500 g/acre in 200 L of water at the first appearance of symptoms.
Final Answer: Bacterial leaf blight is favored by high humidity, warm temperatures, and rainfall. To manage the disease, follow Integrated Disease Management (IDM) practices such as crop rotation with cereals (wheat, maize) or non-host legumes, proper irrigation, and seed treatment with Thiram @ 3 g/kg seed or hot water treatment (56 °C for 10 minutes) to eliminate seed-borne pathogens. Chemical control: Apply a foliar spray of Copper Oxychloride 50% WP @ 400–500 g/acre in 200 L of water at the first appearance of symptoms.

QueryText: Information Regarding Seed Rate Of Bitter Gourd
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding seed rate of Bitter Gourd
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended seed rate of Bitter Gourd?
KccAns: 15 -2 Kg Seed Required For One Acre Spacing Plant To Plant 60 Cm
QueryText_normalized: information regarding seed rate of bitter gourd
Primary Answer (Level0): The seed rate recommended is 1.5 to 2.0 kg, and it is sufficient for one acre. Some of the varieties of Bitter Gourd with this seed rate are Pusa Rasdar (an early variety harvested in 41–45 days with juicy fruits, smooth, non-prickled, tender skin, fleshy, dark green colour, average fruit weight 110 g, good yield). Pusa Purvi is another small-fruited bitter gourd variety for stuffed cuisines. Its fruits are dark green, small (4–5 cm long and 3–4 cm diameter), crispy, with high dry matter. Average yield is 35 q/acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
The seed rate recommended in the state of Haryana is 1.5 to 2.0 kg and it is sufficient for one acre.

Some of the varieties of Bitter Gourd which has this seed rate is Pusa Rasdar which is an early variety which can be harvested in 41-45 days with juicy fruits, smooth, non-prickled with tender skin, fleshy and has desirable marketable attributes like atractive dark green colour. Average fruit weight is 110 g with an average yield.
Pusa Purvi is another variety small fruited bitter gourd variety for making stuffed cuisines. Its fruits are of dark green colour, small size(4-5 cm long and 3-4 diameter) and crispy flesh with high dry matter. Average yield is 35 q/acre.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect Seed Rate: The seed rate of 2.5-3.5 kg per acre is for old, open-pollinated varieties. This is a major error. The vast majority of commercial cultivation uses F1 hybrids, for which the seed rate is much lower, around 400-500 grams per acre. Recommending the wrong rate would cause a huge financial loss.

Incomplete Spacing Info: It gives a plant-to-plant spacing ("1m between plants") but fails to mention the crucial row-to-row spacing.

QueryText: How To Control Of Alternaria Blight In Mustard Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Alternaria Blight in Mustard crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Alternaria Blight in Mustard?
KccAns: Spray To Daithen M-45  600Gm In 250 Litres Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of alternaria blight in mustard crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Alternaria Blight in Mustard shows circular dark brown to black spots on leaves with concentric rings; lesions may also appear on stems and pods. To control, spray Indofil M-45 (Mancozeb 75% WP) @ 500 gm/ac or Kavach (Chlorothalonil 75% WP) @ 400 g/ac, and maintain proper field sanitation.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Alternaria Blight in mustard is identified by circular dark brown to black spots with concentric rings on the leaves, stems and pods. To manage this disease effectively, spray Indofil M-45 (Mancozeb 75% WP) at 500 g/acre or Kavach (Chlorothalonil 75% WP) at 400 g/acre. Maintain proper field sanitation to reduce the spread of infection. For best results, apply the first spray at the initial appearance of spots on the lower leaves. If weather conditions are cloudy and humid at pod formation stage second spray should be applied 15–20 days after the first to ensure effective disease control.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Strategic Timing: The advice would be complete if it specified when to spray. The first spray should be applied at the first appearance of spots on the lower leaves. A second spray may be required 15-20 days later, especially if the weather remains cloudy and humid during the pod formation stage.

QueryText: How To Control Alternaria Blight In Radish Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Alternaria Blight in Radish crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Alternaria Blight in Radish crop?
KccAns: Spray Of Indophil M-45  400 Gm In 200 Liter Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control alternaria blight in radish crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Alternaria blight in radish is a fungal disease causing small dark brown to black spots on leaves. Leaf margins dry up, plants become weak and stunted, reducing yield. It spreads more in cool, moist weather and from infected plant waste. To control, spray Mancozeb 75% WP at 600–800 g/acre in 200 L water. For better, longer protection, also spray Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% SC at 300 ml/acre in 200 L water. Repeat after 10–12 days if moist weather continues. Start sprays at first spots. Avoid overhead irrigation, keep the field clean, don’t repeat radish in the same land, always use healthy seeds, and remove infected plants after harvest. By doing all this, farmers can save the crop and get better yield and price in the market. All sprays mentioned are safe and commonly used in radish fields.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
Alternaria blight in radish is a fungus disease that causes small dark brown to black spots on the leaves. Slowly, the leaf edges or leaf margins dry up, and the plant becomes weak and stunted. This reduces growth and yield. The disease spreads more during cool and moist weather, and also from infected plant waste if not removed from the land.
To control it, spray Mancozeb 75% WP at 600–800 grams per acre in 200 litres of water at first appearance of symptoms. This helps stop the fungus from spreading. For better and longer protection, you can also spray a mix of Azoxystrobin 11% and Tebuconazole 18.3% SC at 300 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. If the weather stays moist, repeat the spray after 10–12 days if needed. Start spraying as soon as spots are seen on leaves. Avoid overhead watering like sprinklers, as wet leaves increase the disease. Keep the field clean, do not plant radish again and again in the same land, and always use clean, healthy certified disease-free seeds and practice 2-3 years crop rotation for better resistance management. Remove old infected plants after harvest. By doing all this steps, farmers can protect the crop and get better yield and price in the market. All sprays mentioned are safe and commonly used in radish fields.

QueryText: How To Control Of Alternaria Leaf Spot In Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Alternaria Leaf Spot in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Alternaria Leaf Spot in Cotton?
KccAns: Spray To Blitox  500Gm In 200 Litres Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of alternaria leaf spot in cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Alternaria leaf spot in cotton is caused by Alternaria macrospora, common in humid and warm weather. To control, give seed treatment with Carbendazim 63% + Mancozeb 12% WP 2 g/kg of seeds, do soil solarization. If symptoms appear, spray Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 500 g/acre in 500 L water or Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% @ 200 ml/acre in 200 L water. Use certified disease-free seeds, avoid water stagnation, and remove infected leaves.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Alternaria leaf spot in cotton is caused by the fungus Alternaria macrospora, which is caused in humid and warm weather, which is common in Fatehabad. To control it, give seed treatment of Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63% WP 2g/kg of seeds or Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800 gm per acre, do soil solarization. If symptoms appear, spray Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 500 gm/acre in 500 liters of water or Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% 200ml/acre in 200 litres of water. Use certified disease-free seeds, avoid water stagnation, and remove and destroy infected leaves.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Correct Scientific Name: Change "Alternaria macrospore" to "Alternaria macrospora". Missing 'a' in species name.
- Change "Carbendazim 63% + Mancozeb 12%" to "Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63%". The percentages are reversed.
- Add "or Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800 gm per acre" as an alternative effective treatment.

Grammar Corrections:

- "cause by humid" should be "caused by humid"
- "If symptoms are appear" should be "If symptoms appear"

To control it, give seed treatment of Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63% WP 2g/kg of seeds or Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800 gm per acre, do soil solarization. If symptoms appear, spray Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 500 gm/acre in 500 liters of water or Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% 200ml/acre in 200 litres of water. Use certified disease-free seeds, avoid water stagnation, and remove and destroy infected leaves.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Alternaria leaf spot is a fungal disease caused by Alternaria macrospora. It primarily develops and spreads under the warm and humid weather conditions. Effective management requires a combination of preventive and control measures. Preventive Measures (Before and During Sowing) Proactive steps are crucial to minimize the risk of infection. Always use certified, disease-free seeds as the first line of defense. Before sowing, treat seeds with Carbendazim 12% + Mancozeb 63% WP at a rate of 2 g per kg of seeds. Ensure proper field drainage to avoid water stagnation, as excess moisture promotes fungal growth. If you notice symptoms on the leaves, take immediate action to control the spread. Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant debris to reduce the source of fungal spores in the field. You can also do soil solarization as an additional measure to reduce soil-borne pathogens before planting. If the disease is spreading, apply one of the following fungicides, ensuring thorough coverage by using approximately 200 liters of water per acre: Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600-800 g/acre, Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 500 g/acre, Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% SC @ 200 ml/acre. Use a high volume of water, typically 200-250 liters per acre, to ensure the spray reaches all parts of the plant, especially the underside of the leaves. To prevent resistance, do not use the same chemical class repeatedly. Apply the spray in the early morning or late afternoon when temperatures are lower and the wind is calm.

QueryText: How To Control Caterpilar In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control caterpillars in Cotton crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control the Caterpillar (American Bollworm) in Cotton?
KccAns: Spray 25 Ml Monocrotophous  200 Litre Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control caterpilar in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): American bollworm is one of the most dangerous pests in cotton, reducing yield by up to 50%. To control during the Zaid season, start monitoring from 30 days after sowing. Look for holes in squares/bolls, frass, and caterpillars. For severe infestation, use insecticides like Emamectin benzoate 5 SG @ 220–250 g/acre, Spinosad 45 SC @ 75–100 ml/acre, or Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC. Spray in the evening, avoid repeating the same chemical, remove damaged bolls, and deep plough after harvest. Rotate chemicals to prevent resistance.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Cotton is a kharif crop in Haryana, not a zaid crop.American bollworm is one of the most dangerous pest in cotton. It can reduce yield by up to 50% if not controlled in time.To control American bollworm in cotton, start monitoring from 30 days after sowing. Look for holes in squares or bolls, frass, and greenish caterpillars. For severe infestation, use selective insecticides like Emamectin benzoate 5 SG @ 220–250 g/ acre , Spinosad 45 SC @ 75–100 ml/ acre, or Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC @ in the evening. Avoid repeat use of the same chemical. Remove damaged bolls and deep plough after harvest. Spray in evening for best results. Avoid mixing insecticides and rotate different chemical to prevent resistance. Additionally, always be mindful of the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) for each pesticide, as it is critical for safety. Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI)—14 days for Emamectin, 7 days for Spinosad, and 15 days for Chlorantraniliprole—to ensure safety for workers during picking.

QueryText: Information Regarding To Improved The Varities Of Basmati Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the improved varieties of Basmati Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which improved Basmati rice varieties are most suitable for cultivation?
KccAns: I Told The Kisan To Improved The Varities Of Basmati Paddy Is Pr47Csr30Pusa1460
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to improved the varities of basmati paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): An important point: Basmati paddy is a Kharif crop and cannot be grown in Zaid (summer) due to specific weather needs. For the Kharif season, improved variety selection is key. For the highest price due to extra-long grain, choose Pusa Basmati 1121. For early maturity to fit wheat after harvest, use Pusa Basmati 1509. For a low-risk option resistant to Bacterial Blight, use Pusa Basmati 1718, which saves ₹2000–2500/acre on sprays.
Source [Name and Link]:
"PIB, Government of India: https://www.pib.gov.in/PressReleasePage.aspx?PRID=1863885

APEDA (Basmati Rice Official): https://apeda.gov.in/BasmatiRice

MoSPI Case Study on Basmati: https://www.mospi.gov.in/case-study-of-gdkp

ICAR-IARI Rice Varieties: https://ztmbpd.iari.res.in/technologies/varietieshybrids/cereals/rice/

NCBI (Peer-reviewed background on PB1121): https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5890003/"
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): An important point first: Basmati paddy is a Kharif season crop in Haryana and cannot be grown in the Zaid (summer) season due to its specific weather requirements for proper growth and grain quality. For the main Kharif season, choosing the right improved variety is the key to your profit. For the absolute highest market price due to its world-famous extra-long grain, the best choice is Pusa Basmati 1121. If your priority is to harvest early to prepare your field on time for the next wheat crop, then the early-maturing Pusa Basmati 1509 is perfect. For a smart, low-risk option, consider Pusa Basmati 1718, which is resistant to the Bacterial Blight disease and can save you ₹2000-2500 per acre on chemical sprays.

QueryText: The Control Of Angular Leaf Spot In Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Angular Leaf Spot in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Angular Leaf Spot in Cotton?
KccAns: Spray Of Blitox  500 Gm In 200 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: the control of angular leaf spot in cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Angular leaf spot in cotton appears as small, angular water-soaked spots with yellow halos on leaves. To control it during zaid season in Jind, use seeds treated with streptomycin (about 100 grams per acre) and plant resistant varieties. Remove old crop debris and do deep ploughing before sowing. Use drip irrigation and maintain about 30-inch row spacing. For sprays, apply streptomycin sulphate at 250 grams per acre (mixed in 100 liters water) or copper oxychloride at 300 grams per acre (3 grams per liter), starting at first symptoms and repeat 3–4 times at 15-day intervals. Spray early morning or late evening and scout fields every 10 days.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Angular leaf spot in cotton appears as small, angular water-soaked spots with yellow halos on leaves. To control it during zaid season in Jind, treat seeds with 1 gram of streptocyclin mixed in 10 litres of water. Remove old crop debris and do deep ploughing before sowing. Use drip irrigation and maintain about 30-inch row spacing. For sprays, apply streptomycin sulphate at 6-8 grams per acre (mixed in 150-200 liters water) or copper oxychloride at 600-800 grams per acre, starting at first symptoms and repeat 3–4 times at 15-day intervals. Spray early morning or late evening and scout fields every 10 days.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- The Correct growing season for cotton in Haryana.   

- Recommending seed treatment with "streptomycin (about 100 grams per acre)" is not a standard unit. The correct method is based on the weight of the seed. The recommendation should be changed to a standard practice, such as "treat seeds with 1 gram of streptocyclin mixed in 10 litres of water".   

- Spraying "streptomycin sulphate at 250 grams per acre" is a severe overdose. The correct recommendation is 6-8 grams per acre.   
- Spraying "copper oxychloride at 300 grams per acre" is a significant underdose. The correct rate is 600-800 grams per acre.   
- The spray volume should be increased from "100 liters water" to the recommended 150-200 litres per acre for effective application on cotton.

QueryText: How To Control Of Anthracnose  Scab In Bottle Gourd
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Anthracnose and Scab in Bottle Gourd?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Anthracnose and Scab in Bottle Gourd?
KccAns: Spray To Indofil M-45  200Gm In 100 Liter Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of anthracnose scab in bottle gourd
Primary Answer (Level0): Anthracnose and Scab are fungal diseases that cause dark, sunken spots on your bottle gourd fruits, making them unmarketable. To control both diseases effectively, you must rotate fungicides. For a preventive or early-stage spray, a contact + systemic combination like Azoxystrobin + Tebuconazole at 200 ml per acre is a modern and highly effective option. As an alternative for rotation, you can use Copper Oxychloride + Mancozeb combinations. A crucial expert tip is to also remove and destroy any infected leaves and fruits to reduce the spread of the fungus in your field. Most importantly, after spraying, you must wait for at least 5-7 days (the Pre-Harvest Interval) before harvesting any fruit to ensure the vegetables are completely safe for consumption.
Source [Name and Link]:
"International Journal of Chemical Studies (Integrated Management): https://www.chemijournal.com/archives/2020/vol8issue1/PartQ/8-1-148-514.pdf

Efficacy of Fungicides (Indian study): https://www.phytojournal.com/archives/2020/vol9issue4/PartF/9-4-2-423.pdf

Katyayani (Azoxystrobin + Tebuconazole label): https://katyayanikrishidirect.com/products/katyayani-dr-zole-azoxystrobin-11-tebuconazole-18-30-sc-fungicide

Adama India (Fungicide product): https://krushidukan.bharatagri.com/en/products/adama-custodia-azoxystrobin-11-tebuconazole-18-3-fungicide

Premia Fungicide (Label info): https://farmmate.in/products/azoxystrobin-11-tebuconazole-18-3-sc-fungicide-fungicides"

Most importantly, after spraying, you must wait for at least 5-7 days (the Pre-Harvest Interval) before harvesting any fruit to ensure the vegetables are completely safe for consumption.
Final Answer: Anthracnose and Scab are fungal diseases that cause dark, sunken spots on your bottle gourd fruits, making them unmarketable. To control both diseases effectively, you must rotate fungicides. For a preventive or early-stage spray, a contact + systemic combination like Azoxystrobin + Tebuconazole at 200 ml per acre is a modern and highly effective option. As an alternative for rotation, you can use Copper Oxychloride + Mancozeb combinations. A crucial expert tip is to also remove and destroy any infected leaves and fruits to reduce the spread of the fungus in your field. Most importantly, after spraying, you must wait for at least 5-7 days (the Pre-Harvest Interval) before harvesting any fruit to ensure the vegetables are completely safe for consumption.

QueryText: How To Control Of Anthracnose In Papaya
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Anthracnose in Papaya?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Anthracnose in Papaya?
KccAns: Spray To Indofil M-45  200Gm In 100 Liter Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of anthracnose in papaya
Primary Answer (Level0): Anthracnose in papaya causes dark, sunken spots on fruits and leaves, leading to fruit rot and reduced market value. To control anthracnose in papaya spray Mancozeb 75 WP (2.5 g/l).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Anthracnose is a common fungal disease in papaya that causes dark, sunken spots on the fruits. These spots later turn black and can spoil the fruit completely if not controlled on time. To manage this first try to use only disease-free and certified seeds or seedlings. Keeping proper spacing between plants is also important, as it helps in good air movement and prevents fungus from developing. Try to avoid overhead irrigation, using drip irrigation is better, as it keeps the leaves and fruits dry. Also, regularly check your plants and remove any infected leaves or fruits from the field to stop the disease from spreading. For natural prevention, you can spray bio-fungicides like Trichoderma viride or Pseudomonas fluorescens at 5–10 grams per litre of water. If the infection becomes serious, then you can spray Chlorothalonil 75 WP at 2 grams per litre or Tebuconazole 25.9 EC at 0.5 ml per litre of water. Do not spray any chemical pesticide 3 weeks before harvesting of papaya so that the pesticide residue breaks down and the fruits become safe for consumption.

Incomplete Chemical Strategy: It only recommends a contact fungicide (Mancozeb). For a disease that affects fruit quality, an expert strategy involves rotating with a systemic fungicide (like Tebuconazole) for better protection.

QueryText: Control Of Aphid In Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Cotton?
KccAns: Spray Of Rogor  250 Ml In 120 Liters Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of aphid in cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphid causes yellow and curled leaves in cotton, so early control is necessary. Controlling aphids in cotton requires an integrated pest management approach that combines cultural, biological, and chemical methods. Remove weeds and plant debris from and around cotton field, use yellow sticky traps that can monitor and control aphids, encourage or release lady birds beetle or lacewings, and if infestation is severe, rotate insecticide spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100-125 ml per acre mixed in 200 litres of water or Diafenthiuron 50 WP @ 240-300 grams per acre mixed in 200 litres of water to prevent aphid resistance.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Cotton, aphid causes yellow and curled leaves, excrete honey dew on leaves on which black fungus develops. Petioles, internodes, flowers, buds, mature bolls and even leaves fall down and growth of the plant is retarded. Aphids control is most critical during the early to mid-vegetative stage of the crop.  Controlling aphids in cotton requires an Integrated Pest Management(IPM) approach that combines cultural, biological, and chemical methods. Remove weeds and plant debris from and around cotton field, use yellow sticky traps that can monitor and control aphids, encourage or release lady birds beetle and lacewings, and if infestation is severe, rotate insecticides by spraying either Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100–125 ml per acre mixed in 200 litres of water, (costing around ₹200–300 per acre) or Diafenthiuron 50 WP @ 240–300 grams per acre also in 200 litres of water, (costing about ₹500–600 per acre), ensuring better control and long-term effectiveness.

QueryText: How To Control Aphids In Bottle Gourd

Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids are a frequent pest on the bottle guard. These sap sucking insects can distort leaves, stunt growth, and transmit serious viruses like CMV or ZYMV. To control aphids in bottle guard give seed treatment with Imidacloprid 70% WS @ 5g/kg of seeds, use yellow sticky traps to monitor the aphids if they cross ETL spray immediately Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 40 g/acre in 200 litre of water or Fipronil 5% SC 250 ml/acre in 150-200 litre of water. Spray early morning or evening to avoid leaf scorching and to protect pollinators.

QueryText_normalized: informatyion regarding how to control aphids in potato
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids are a major pest of potatoes in North India, especially because they transmit viral diseases like PVY and PLRV, To control aphids in potato during Rabi season, you need an integrated approach combining monitoring, cultural practices, biological (Use yellow sticky traps), Introduce natural enemies like lacewings, Organic Apply Neem oil 2% or Azadirachtin 1500 ppm, spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL- 100ml in 200 L water, Thiamethoxam 25% WG 80g in 200 L of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids are a major pest of potatoes in North India (including Panipat), especially because they transmit viral diseases like PVY and PLRV, To control aphids in potato during Rabi season in Panipat, you need an integrated approach combining monitoring, cultural practices, biological (Use yellow sticky traps), Introduce natural enemies like lacewings, Organic Apply Neem oil 2% or Azadirachtin 1500 ppm, spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL- 50ml per acre in 200 L water.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Imidacloprid 17.8 SL rate should be 50 ml/acre, not 100 ml in 200 L.

- Thiamethoxam foliar use on tuber crops is restricted after tuber initiation; omit the 80 g spray and rely on seed‐tuber treatment only.

Comment (Reviewer2): PHI missing.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Aphids are a major pest of Potatoes, especially because they transmit viral diseases such as PVY and PLRV. To control aphids in potato during the Rabi season, an integrated approach combining monitoring, cultural practices, and biological methods is required. Monitoring: Use yellow sticky traps. Biological control: Introduce natural enemies such as lacewings. Organic control: Apply neem oil 2% or azadirachtin 1500 ppm. Chemical control: Spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 50 ml per acre in 200 L of water; PHI: 7 days (repeat every 14 days).

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray 350 Ml Applaud 200 Gm Acephate In 200 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control aphids in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids are sap sucking pest which feeds on tender paddy shoots and can also transmit the viral disease which can severely damage the crop to control aphids in paddy avoid excess nitrogen and late sowing, Spray Flupyradifurone 17.1% SL @200ml/acre in 500 litres of water, or Sulfoxaflor 50% WG @ 100 g/acre in 500 litre of water, Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 100g/acre in 500 litre of water. Rotate the sprays group so that pest resistance did not develop.

Rotate the spray group so that pest resistance does not develop.

QueryText: Information Regarding To Control Aphids In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Aphids in the Wheat crop?
KccAns: Spray Confidor 100 Ml In 150 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to control aphids in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids are small insects that suck plant juice, making wheat plants weak and yellow. They attack mostly in late crop stages (after flowering), especially when the weather is cool and dry. If not controlled in time, aphids can reduce grain size and final yield. To control aphids in wheat, spray Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 80 gram per acre or Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 100 ml per acre, mixed in 200 liters of water. These are easily available and give good results. Spray when aphid numbers are seen on 8–10 plants out of 100 plants (that's mean it is ETL - Economic Threshold Level of aphids in wheat), at this time you have to take action immediately. For better results, spray in the morning or evening when wind is low. As an alternative, also you can use  Flonicamid 50% WG @ 60 gram per acre in 200 litres of water  for good control and better resistance. As a safer option and for bio control, you can also use Neem-based insecticide (Azadirachtin 1500 ppm) @ 300–400 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Rotate chemicals every season to avoid resistance. Keep the field clean after harvest to reduce future pest attack. Always read the label before spraying and wear protective clothes.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids are small insects that suck plant juice, making wheat plants weak and yellow. They attack mostly in late crop stages (after flowering), especially when the weather is cool and dry. If not controlled in time, aphids can reduce grain size and final yield. To control aphids in wheat, spray Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 100 gram per acre or Imidacloprid 17.8% SL @ 100 ml per acre, mixed in 200 liters of water. These are easily available in Haryana and give good results. Spray when aphid numbers are seen 5 aphids per ear head or 10-15 aphids per tiller (that's mean it is ETL - Economic Threshold Level of aphids in wheat), at this time you have to take action immediately. For better results, spray in the morning or evening when wind is low. As an alternative, also you can use  Flonicamid 50% WG @ 60 gram per acre in 200 litres of water  for good control and better resistance. As a safer option and for bio control, you can also use Neem-based insecticide (Azadirachtin 1500 ppm) @ 300–400 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Rotate chemicals every season to avoid resistance. Keep the field clean after harvest to reduce future pest attack. Along with spraying, also practice cultural methods like removing weeds around the field and destroying aphid-infested plant parts. Encourage natural enemies like ladybird beetles and hoverflies, which feed on aphids. After harvest, remove and destroy crop residues to stop the next generation. Always read the label before spraying and wear protective clothes.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Update ETL Information: Change "8-10 plants out of 100 plants" to "5 aphids per ear head or 10-15 aphids per tiller". This is the correct Economic Threshold Level.

- Correct Dosage: Change "Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 80 gram per acre" to "Thiamethoxam 25% WG @ 100 gram per acre". The current dosage is too low.

QueryText: Control Of Aphid In Guar
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Guar (Cluster bean)?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Guar (Cluster bean)?
KccAns: Spray Of Malathion 50Ec  200Ml In 200 Liters Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: control of aphid in guar
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids causes leaf curling and stunted growth in guar (cluster bean).Use early sowing (late March to early April) to escape peak infestation. Keep field weed-free because weeds attract aphids. Avoid excess nitrogen, it promotes tender growth that leads to aphid attraction. To control aphids in guar during the zaid season in sirsa, spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 100 ml per acre in 200 liters of water when infestation starts. Alternatively, Neem oil (2%) can be used as an organic option. Regular monitoring and removing infested plants help reduce aphid buildup. Spray early morning or late evening for best results.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids causes leaf curling and stunted growth in guar (cluster bean).Use early sowing (late March to early April) to escape peak infestation. Keep field weed-free because weeds attract aphids. Avoid excess nitrogen, it promotes tender growth that leads to aphid attraction. To control aphids in guar during the zaid season in sirsa, spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 100 ml per acre in 200 liters of water when infestation starts. Alternatively, Neem oil (2%) can be used as an organic option. Regular monitoring and removing infested plants help reduce aphid buildup. Spray early morning or late evening for best results. For Imidacloprid, the PHI is typically 7–10 days. This means that if you're harvesting guar for green pods, you should not apply Imidacloprid within 7–10 days of harvesting to avoid pesticide residues on the pods.

QueryText: How can I Control Aphids In Lemon?
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Lemon?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Lemon?
KccAns: Spray 1 Ml Rogor In Per Lt Of Water
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control aphids in lemon
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids in lemon crops generally occurs during spring (Feb-March) and post-monsoon like in (Sept-Oct ) season, for controlling it you can use yellow sticky traps (10/acre), also you can used marigold as a Trap crop and which are very helpful against aphids, also you can take a Spray of neem oil 5ml/lit. or imidacloprid 0.5ml/lit. also Prune infested shoots and encourage natural predators like ladybugs. you can use Resistant varieties like Pusa Udit or Kagzi Kalan which show better tolerance and also give high yield.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids in lemon crops generally occur during spring (Feb-March) and post-monsoon (Sept-Oct) season. To control them, you can use yellow sticky traps (10/acre). Also, you can use marigolds as a trap crop, which are very helpful against aphids. Also, you can sprayneem oil (150-180 ml/acre) or imidacloprid (80-90 ml/acre). Also, prune infested shoots and encourage natural predators like ladybugs. You can use resistant varieties like Pusa Udit or Kagzi Kalan, which show better tolerance and also give high yield.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Impractical Dosage: The dose for Imidacloprid is given per litre. For spraying trees in an orchard, this is not a practical measurement. The answer must provide the standard per-acre rate (e.g., 60-80 ml per acre).

Missing Strategic Timing: The most critical advice is missing. It fails to mention that sprays for sucking pests like aphids are most effective and important during the new leaf flush and flowering stages when the growth is tender and most vulnerable to attack.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Aphids in lemon crops generally occur during spring (Feb-March) and post-monsoon (Sept-Oct) season. To control them, you can use yellow sticky traps (10/acre). Also, you can use marigolds as a trap crop, which are very helpful against aphids. Also, you can sprayneem oil (150-180 ml/acre) or imidacloprid (80-90 ml/acre). Also, prune infested shoots and encourage natural predators like ladybugs. You can use resistant varieties like Pusa Udit or Kagzi Kalan, which show better tolerance and also give high yield.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Neem oil dose is too low — 150–180 ml/acre won’t be effective; should be 2–3 ml/liter (400–600 ml/acre).

Pusa Udit and Kagzi Kalan not widely recorded for aphid resistance — more for fruit quality.

Also, you can use marigolds as a trap crop, which are very helpful against aphids. Also, you can spray neem oil (400-500 ml/acre) or imidacloprid (80-90 ml/acre). Also, prune infested shoots and encourage natural predators like ladybugs. You can use slightly resistant varieties like Pusa Udit or Kagzi Kalan, which show better tolerance and also give high yield.

QueryText: Control Of Aphid In Okra

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Okra?
KccAns: Spray Of Malathion  400Ml In 200 Liters Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: control of aphid in okra
Primary Answer (Level0): Aphids suck sap from plant parts, from young shoots and leaves, causing the leaves to curling ,Black sooty mould develops on the leaf surface due to the excretion of honeydew by the aphids, to control spray Acetamiprid 20 SP @ 75 g/acre, Tolfenpyrad 15 EC @ 2.0 1000 ml/acre, Imidacloprid 200 SL @ 40 ml/acre or Dimethoate 30 EC @ 500 ml/acre. Botanically, you can also control aphids by spraying NSKE (Neem Seed Kernel Extract) 5% @ 200 liters/acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids suck sap from young shoots and leaves, causing leaf curling and promoting the growth of black sooty mold due to their honeydew secretions. To control aphids chemically, spray safer insecticides such as Acetamiprid 20 SP at 75 g/acre or Imidacloprid 200 SL at 40 ml/acre, following recommended doses carefully. Avoid using highly toxic chemicals like Dimethoate on crops like okra to prevent harmful residues. Botanical control using Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE) 5% at 200 liters/acre is also effective and eco-friendly. Always observe the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) for all chemicals to ensure crop safety and consumer health. Additionally, regular monitoring and integrated pest management practices can help reduce aphid populations sustainably.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Recommends a Dangerous Chemical: It recommends Dimethoate. This is a highly toxic organophosphate and is generally not recommended for frequently harvested vegetables like okra due to high residue risk.

Critical Safety Omission: The advice is completely unsafe as it omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period for all recommended chemicals, which is non-negotiable for okra.

QueryText: Information Regarding Fertilizers Dose In Methi
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding fertilizer dose in Methi (Fenugreek)
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended fertilizer dose of Methi (Fenugreek)?
KccAns: 8 Ton Fm Y 50 Kg Urea  40 Kg Dpp Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding fertilizers dose in methi
Primary Answer (Level0): Apply 8 tons Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate in per acre of area at the time of sowing.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Apply 8 tons Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate in per acre of area at the time of sowing.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Excessive Phosphorus Dose: The recommendation of 125 kg Single Super Phosphate (SSP) per acre is excessively high for a short-duration, low-requirement crop like Methi (Fenugreek). The standard recommended dose is much lower, around 50-60 kg of SSP per acre.

Missing Potash: The recommendation omits a small dose of Potash (e.g., 15-20 kg of Muriate of Potash per acre), which is generally advised for better plant health and quality.
Note for Reviewer1:
I have followed 
https://emausamhau.com/cropdetailh.aspx?id=4107 as per haryana agriculture university.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Apply 8 tons Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate in per acre of area at the time of sowing.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Consider adding a small dose of potash (15–20 kg/acre) if soils are low in K.

Suggest applying half nitrogen at sowing and the remainder at first weeding to match crop uptake.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): During land preparation, apply 8 tonnes of Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea, and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate per acre at the time of sowing. Add a small dose of Muriate of Potash (15–20 kg/acre) if soil tests show low potassium levels. To improve nutrient use efficiency, apply half of the nitrogen at sowing and the remaining half at the first weeding stage for better growth and yield.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): During land preparation, apply 8 tonnes of Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea, and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate per acre at the time of sowing. To improve nutrient use efficiency, apply half of the nitrogen at sowing and the remaining half at the first weeding stage for better growth and yield.

To improve nutrient use efficiency, apply half of the nitrogen at sowing and the remaining half at the first weeding stage for better growth and yield.
Final Answer: During land preparation, apply 8 tonnes of Farmyard Manure (FYM), 22 kg Urea, and 125 kg Single Super Phosphate per acre at the time of sowing. Add a small dose of Muriate of Potash (15–20 kg/acre) if soil tests show low potassium levels. To improve nutrient use efficiency, apply half of the nitrogen at sowing and the remaining half at the first weeding stage for better growth and yield.

QueryText: Information Regarding To The Improved Varities Of Arhar Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the improved varieties of Arhar (Pigeon pea) crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which are the improved varieties of Arhar (Pigeon pea)?
KccAns: I Told The Kisan The Improved Varities Of Arhar Crop Are Upas-120T-21Manakparas
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to the improved varities of arhar crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Arhar (pigeon pea) it's an short duration crop which give high profit in less time so for your region you can used Pusa 992 which performs well in irrigated conditions, also it is well suitable for cultivation, it is also resistance to wilt and sterility mosaic disease, it give yields upto 18-20 quintals/hec. approx. and starts flowering in 120-125 days. For rainfed areas, you can go with IPH 15-03 it is recommended with moderate drought tolerance and resistance to phytophthora blight, which give yield upto 15-17 quintals/hec. with flowering in 130-135 days. In saline soil condition You can take ICPL-151 it is better adapted with moderate salt tolerance, producing 14-16 quintals/hec. approx. and flowering in 125-130 days. and for early maturity, Pusa Arhar 16 is best variety and it is demanding in haryana side it will complete flowering time in 100-110 days and it is also resistant to wilt and pod borer, it gives yield upto 16-18 quintals/hec. approx.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Arhar (pigeon pea) is a short-duration crop that gives high profit in less time, so for the Haryana region, you can use Pusa 992, which performs well in irrigated conditions. Also, it is well-suited for cultivation, and it is also resistant to wilt and sterility mosaic disease. It gives yields up to approx. 18-20 q/acre and starts flowering in 120-125 days. For rainfed areas, you can go with AL 201; it is recommended with moderate drought tolerance and resistance to phytophthora blight, which gives a yield of up to 15-17 q/acre, with flowering in 130-135 days. In saline soil conditions, you can take Pusa 855; it is better adapted with moderate salt tolerance, producing approximately 14-16 q/acre and flowering in 125-130 days. And for early maturity, Pusa Arhar 16 is the best variety, and it is in demand in the Haryana side. It will complete flowering time in 100-110 days, and it is also resistant to wilt and pod borer. It gives a yield of up to 16-18 q/acre, approx.

QueryText: How To Control Of Gulli Danda In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Gulli danda (Phalaris minor) in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Gulli danda (Phalaris minor) in Wheat crop?
KccAns: Spray To Topic160Gm In 200 Liter Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of gulli danda in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): As soon as you see Gulli Danda disease, spray Propiconazole 25% EC at 200 ml per acre or mixed in 200 litres of water. Donâ€™t delay the spray â€” early control is best. If the disease is severe, spray again after 10 days. Avoid spraying in the evening or during rain. Make sure the whole plant is well covered. This disease reduces both yield and grain quality.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Gulli Danda (Phalaris minor) is a major weed in wheat fields that looks similar to wheat and grows rapidly, making it hard to identify early. It competes for nutrients, water, and sunlight, leading to significant yield loss if not controlled in time. The best control method is timely application of post-emergence herbicide at the 2–4 leaf stage of the weed. Farmers should spray either  Leader 75 WG (Sulfosulfuron) at 13 grams per acre or Axial 5 EC (Pinoxaden) at 400 ml per acre, mixed in 150 litres of water. Spraying should be done during clear weather, not in the evening or rainy conditions, and full field coverage is necessary for effective control. For better control Gulli Danda, avoid using the same chemical group repeatedly. Instead, rotate or alternate herbicides with different modes of action every year. Also, using resistant wheat varieties like PBW 343, HD 2967, or DBW 187 helps reduce infestation. Additionally, follow up with Tebuconazole or Triadimefon sprays in alternate years to manage resistance build-up in weeds and associated diseases. Timely and proper weed management not only saves yield but also improves grain quality.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Gulli Danda (Phalaris minor) is a weed, not a disease, a fungicide like Propiconazole 25 EC will have no effect. It must be controlled with a post-emergence herbicide

Replace Propiconazole 25% EC (a fungicide) with a postâ€emergence herbicide, e.g.:
â€“ Leader 75 WG (sulfosulfuron) at 13 g/acre
â€“ OR Axial 5 EC (pinoxaden) at 400 ml/acre in 150 L water.

Remove all â€œper bighaâ€ referencesâ€”use only acre-based rates.

Spray when gulli danda plants are at the 2â€“4 leaf stage, not â€œas soon as" you see that

QueryText: How To Control Aphids In Brinjal Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Brinjal crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Brinjal?
KccAns: How To Control Aphids In Brinjal Crop-Spray 400 Ml Malathion In 200 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control aphids in brinjal crop
Primary Answer (Level0): At the first sign of infestation—leaf curling, yellowing, stunted growth, and sticky honeydew—begin with 3 sprays of 5% NSKE (neem seed kernel extract) at 7–10 day intervals. If the infestation is severe, apply chemical control using Acetamiprid 20% SP at 60–80 g per acre Or Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 100–150 ml per acre. Enhance control by deploying yellow sticky traps @ 2–3 per acre. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, maintain clean fields, and rotate insecticides to prevent resistance development.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): At the first sign of infestation—leaf curling, yellowing, stunted growth, and sticky honeydew—begin with 3 sprays of 5% NSKE (neem seed kernel extract) at 7–10 day intervals. If the infestation is severe, apply chemical control using Acetamiprid 20% SP at 60–80 g per acre Or Imidacloprid 17.8% SL at 100–150 ml per acre. Enhance control by deploying yellow sticky traps @ 12-15 per acre. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, maintain clean fields, and rotate insecticides to prevent resistance development. For safety, always observe the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) for chemical applications like Acetamiprid 20% SP is typically 7 days and Imidacloprid 17.8% SL is usually 10–14 days depending on the crop. These precautions ensure safe use and minimize pesticide residues on your crops.

QueryText: How To Control Of Bacterial Leaf Spot In Pomegranate
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bacterial Leaf Spot in Pomegranate?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bacterial Leaf Spot in Pomegranate?
KccAns: Spray To Bordeaux Mixture 2:2:250
QueryText_normalized: how to control of bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate
Primary Answer (Level0): Bacterial leaf spots in pomegranate cause black spots on leaves and fruits, leading to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. To control bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, remove and destroy infected leaves and fruits, avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation, and spray copper oxychloride 50 WP @ 2.5 kg per acre in 500 litres of water or spray 1% Bordeaux mixture(1 kg copper sulphate+1 kg lime in 100 litres of water).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Bacterial leaf spots in pomegranate causes black spots on leaves and fruits, leads to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. To control bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, remove and destroy infected leaves and fruits, avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation, and spray copper oxychloride 50 WP @1 kg per acre in 500 litres of water + Streptocycline @ 50 gram per acre for effective control, alternatively spray 1% Bordeaux mixture(1 kg copper sulphate+1 kg lime+ 100 litres of water).
Comment (Reviewer1):
:

Incomplete Chemical Recommendation: The biggest flaw is that it fails to include the most essential component for controlling a severe bacterial infection: an antibiotic like Streptocycline (e.g., at 50 grams per acre), which is always sprayed in combination with a copper fungicide for best results.

Excessive Dosage: The per-acre dose recommended for Copper Oxychloride (2.5 kg) is significantly higher than the standard recommendation, which is closer to 1 kg per acre.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Bacterial leaf spots in pomegranate cause black spots on leaves and fruits, leading to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. To control bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, remove and destroy infected leaves and fruits, avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation, and spray copper oxychloride 50 WP @1 kg per acre in 500 litres of water + Streptocycline @ 50 gram per acre for effective control, alternatively spray 1% Bordeaux mixture(1 kg copper sulphate+1 kg lime+ 100 litres of water).
Comment (Reviewer2):
Not always black spots on fruits - more typically brown to dark brown, water-soaked lesions that can turn black later.

The Streptocycline dose is high. Overuse can lead to resistance and regulatory issues.

The quantity and concentration of Bordeaux mixture is accurate per 100 litres, but dosage per acre isn’t mentioned.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Bacterial leaf spots in pomegranate cause brown to dark brown, water-soaked lesions that can turn black later and lead to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. For controlling bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, an integrated disease management approach combining cultural and chemical methods is recommended. Prune and burn affected branches and fruits, select disease-free seedlings, collect and burn fallen infected leaves and fruits, and avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation in the field. Spray Copper Oxychloride 50 WP @ 600-800 grams per acre in 200 litres of water thoroughly, covering both sides of the leaves and fruits at an interval of 10-15 days for effective control. Alternatively, you can spray 1% Bordeaux mixture (prepared using 2 kg copper sulphate + 2 kg lime in 200 liters of water), especially after pruning and before the onset of the rainy season.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): Bacterial leaf spots in Pomegranate cause brown to dark brown, water-soaked lesions that can turn black later and lead to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. For controlling bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, an integrated disease management approach combining cultural and chemical methods is recommended. Alternatively, you can spray 1% Bordeaux mixture (prepared using 2 kg copper sulphate + 2 kg lime in 200 liters of water), especially after pruning and before the onset of the rainy season.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): Bacterial leaf spots in Pomegranate cause brown to dark brown, water-soaked lesions that can turn black later and lead to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. For controlling bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, an integrated disease management approach combining cultural and chemical methods is recommended. Prune and burn affected branches and fruits, select disease-free seedlings, collect and burn fallen infected leaves and fruits, and avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation in the field. Spray Copper Oxychloride 50 WP @ 600-800 grams per acre in 200 litres of water thoroughly, covering both sides of the leaves and fruits at an interval of 10-15 days for effective control. Alternatively, you can spray 1% Bordeaux mixture (prepared using 2 kg copper sulphate + 2 kg lime in 200 liters of water), especially after pruning and before the onset of the rainy season.
Final Answer: Bacterial leaf spots in Pomegranate cause brown to dark brown, water-soaked lesions that can turn black later and lead to leaf fall and fruit damage, so timely control is important to protect yield. For controlling bacterial leaf spot in pomegranate, an integrated disease management approach combining cultural and chemical methods is recommended. Prune and burn affected branches and fruits, select disease-free seedlings, collect and burn fallen infected leaves and fruits, and avoid overhead irrigation and water stagnation in the field. Spray Copper Oxychloride 50 WP @ 600-800 grams per acre in 200 litres of water thoroughly, covering both sides of the leaves and fruits at an interval of 10-15 days for effective control. Alternatively, you can spray 1% Bordeaux mixture (prepared using 2 kg copper sulphate + 2 kg lime in 200 liters of water), especially after pruning and before the onset of the rainy season.

Primary Answer (Level0): Bajra is a tough crop that thrives in heat and low rainfall. For farmers, HHB 67 Improved-2 is a top choice, it matures early in just 60–65 days and is resistant to downy mildew, a major disease in pearl millet. If you're looking for nutrition and market demand then you can opt for HHB 299 which is a biofortified variety rich in iron and ready in about 80 days. Another strong performer is RHB 177, which tolerates drought well and gives consistent yield even in poor rains. For those needing both grain and fodder, MPMH 21 is ideal, offering high dual-purpose yield and strong disease resistance, making it a secure investment for kharif season.

QueryText: How To Control Bakani In Paddy Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bakanae disease in Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I prevent Bakanae disease in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray Of Bavastin 200G200Lit Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control bakani in paddy crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Bakane in field can be controlled by removing the infected plants from the field in the early stages when the spread is low. If the infection continues spray Propiconazole 1 ml in 1 Liter of water .You may need 200 ml of Propiconazole in 200 Liters for an acre. Alternatively Carbendazim 50% WP of 200 grams in 250 Liters of water. From the next season make sure to do seed treatment with Trichoderma viride .
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Bakanae being a seed borne disease the primary effective strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only. For seed treatment use  Thiram 75% WP. As the seed rate for transplanted crop is 25-30 Kg/acre . The required  Thiram is 2.5 g ram per Kg.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Control Method: It wrongly emphasizes foliar sprays as the primary control. Bakanae is a seed-borne disease, so the only truly effective and economical control is seed treatment before sowing (e.g., with Carbendazim at 2g/kg seed). Spraying in the field is largely ineffective as the pathogen is already systemic.

Incomplete Advice: It mentions seed treatment only for the "next season," which is unhelpful for the current crop. The primary advice should always be to use treated seed.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Bakanae being a seed borne disease the primary effective strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only. For seed treatment use  Thiram 75% WP. As the seed rate for transplanted crop is 25-30 Kg/acre . The required  Thiram is 2.5 g ram per Kg.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Check typo

Write: "Use Thiram 75% WP @ 2.5 g/kg seed or Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/kg seed. Alternatively, treat seeds with hot water (54°C for 10 min) after pre-soaking in water for 8 hrs."

Mention fungicide treatment must be done 24 hrs before sowing for maximum effectiveness.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2):
Since Bakanae is a seed-borne disease, the most effective primary strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only.
For seed treatment, use Thiram 75% WP @ 2.5 g/kg seed or Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/kg seed. Alternatively, treat seeds with hot water (54°C for 10 min) after pre-soaking in water for 8 hrs. Seed treatment should be done 24 hours before sowing to ensure maximum effectiveness.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3):
Since Bakanae is a seed-borne disease, the most effective primary strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only.
For seed treatment, use Thiram 75% WP @ 2.5 g/kg seed or Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/kg seed. Alternatively, treat seeds with hot water (54°C for 10 min) after pre-soaking in water for 8 hrs. Seed treatment should be done 24 hours before sowing to ensure maximum effectiveness.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4):
Since Bakanae is a seed-borne disease, the most effective primary strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only.
For seed treatment, use Thiram 75% WP @ 2.5 g/kg seed or Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/kg seed. Alternatively, treat seeds with hot water (54°C for 10 min) after pre-soaking in water for 8 hrs. Seed treatment should be done 24 hours before sowing to ensure maximum effectiveness.
Final Answer:
Since Bakanae is a seed-borne disease, the most effective primary strategy is seed treatment. Always avoid seeds from contaminated fields and buy seeds from certified and trusted sources only.
For seed treatment, use Thiram 75% WP @ 2.5 g/kg seed or Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/kg seed. Alternatively, treat seeds with hot water (54°C for 10 min) after pre-soaking in water for 8 hrs.. Seed treatment should be done 24 hours before sowing to ensure maximum effectiveness.

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Which varieties of Barley are recommended for cultivation?
KccAns: To The Varities Of Barley Is Bh-393Bh-75
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to the varities of barley
Primary Answer (Level0): Barley is a Rabi season crop grows in October to November and harvested in March to April. It is not suitable for cultivation during the Kharif season. Improved varieties include BH 946, DWRUB 52, RD 2668,RD 2035, RD 2552, these are dual purpose used for both food and fodder whereas ,BH 902 ,BH 393, are grown for only food purpose.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Barley is a Rabi season crop , which was sown in October–November and harvested during March–April it is not recommended in Kharif season due to hot climatic conditions. choose improved varieties-based purpose either fodder or grain . Dual-purpose varieties such as BH 946, DWRUB 52, RD 2668, RD 2035, and RD 2552 are suitable to cultivate for both grain and green fodder which gives 16–18 quintals of grain/ac and 100–120 quintals of fodder/ac. On the other hand, varieties like BH 902 and BH 393 offer higher grain yields, typically in the range of 20–22 quintals/ac only suitable for grain purpose only.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Yield Quantification: The advice would be complete if it included the yield potential in quintals per acre for the key recommended varieties. For example, a food variety like BH 902 can yield 20-22 quintals/acre, while a dual-purpose variety will have a specific grain and fodder yield.

Primary Answer (Level0): Barseem is a rabi fodder crop and not suitable for kharif season. It should be sown from mid-October to early November. Recommended varieties include Wardan, Mescavi, BL-42, and Vardan, which give multiple cuts and high green fodder yield. For kharif, crops like sorghum, bajra, maize, guar, or cowpea are better options.

QueryText: Information Regarding To The Varities Of Radish
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the recommended varieties of Radish
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended varieties of Radish?
KccAns: To The Varities Of Radish Is Pusa Chetaki
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to the varities of radish
Primary Answer (Level0): Based on the Mahendragadh climatic and soil conditions, you can use Pusa Chetki, Pusa Himani, Japanese white, Pusa rReshmiand Punjab White.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Based on the Mahendragadh climatic and soil conditions, you can use Pusa Chetki, Pusa Himani, Japanese white, Pusa rReshmiand Punjab White.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Based on the Mahendragadh climatic and soil conditions, you can use Pusa Chetki, Pusa Himani, Japanese white, Pusa rReshmiand Punjab White.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Grammar-	"Regarding To" ➝ "Regarding" or "Information on..."
Spelling-  	"Varities"	➝ "Varieties"
Capitalization- 	"mahendragadh"	➝ "Mahendragarh"
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Based on the climatic and soil conditions, here are some radish varieties you can consider: Pusa Chetki: This variety is excellent for early harvests and can tolerate heat better than others when sown at the end of the rainy season. You can expect to harvest the radishes in about 45 to 50 days, yielding approximately 80 to 100 quintals per acre.. Pusa Himani: This is a top-quality variety suitable for the main winter season. It is reliable and high-yielding, producing an impressive 100 to 120 quintals per acre. Japanese White: Commonly found in the market, this variety produces long, smooth, white radishes that are popular with customers. It performs well in winter, yielding between 90 to 110 quintals per acre. Pusa Reshmi: This variety is unique because it is primarily grown for its leaves rather than its roots. The leaves are tender and smooth, making them ideal for saag. You can expect around 40 quintals per acre through multiple cuttings. Punjab White: As indicated by its name, this variety originates from Punjab Agricultural University and is well-suited for our area. It is known for its high yield and produces beautiful, long white roots. Expect a yield similar to that of Pusa Himani, around 100 to 120 quintals per acre.

QueryText: How To Control Of Bathu In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bathua (Chenopodium album) in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bathua (Chenopodium album) in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray To Algrip  8Gm In 200 Litres Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of bathu in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Bathua (Chenopodium album), a common broadleaf weed in wheat, can be controlled by spraying  Metsulfuron-methyl @ 8 g/acre around 25-30 days after sowing.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Bathua (Chenopodium album) is a common broadleaf weed in wheat and can be effectively managed by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl at 8 g/acre around 25–30 days after sowing. However, wheat fields in Haryana typically suffer from a mixed weed infestation, including grassy weeds such as Phalaris minor (Mandusi) and Avena ludoviciana (Wild oat). To control both grassy weeds and broad leaf weeds better to use herbicides like Total (Carfentrazone + Clodinafop) or Attraction (Metsulfuron + Clodinafop). Alternatively, for broader broadleaf control, herbicides like 2,4-D or Carfentrazone-ethyl can be used post-emergence at the correct crop stage. Always ensure the spray is done when weeds are young (2–4 leaf stage) and soil moisture is adequate for best results.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incomplete Strategy: It only addresses one weed. Most wheat fields have a mixed weed population, including grassy weeds like Mandusi. An expert answer should recommend a broad-spectrum, ready-mix herbicide that controls both broadleaf and grassy weeds in a single, cost-effective spray.

Sub-optimal Recommendation: While Metsulfuron is good, the most common and effective herbicides for broadleaf weeds are often combinations including 2,4-D or Carfentrazone, which should also be mentioned as primary options.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Bathua (Chenopodium album) is a common broadleaf weed in wheat and can be effectively managed by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl at 8 g/acre around 25–30 days after sowing. Alternatively, for broader broadleaf control, herbicides like 2,4-D or Carfentrazone-ethyl can be used post-emergence at the correct crop stage. Always ensure the spray is done when weeds are young (2–4 leaf stage) and soil moisture is adequate for best results.
Comment (Reviewer2):
"Metsulfuron 8 g/acre" is correct for pure Bathua infestation, but Haryana’s wheat usually has mixed weeds; recommendation should stress weed identification before mixing herbicides.

“Total” and “Attraction” are brand names—better to mention active ingredients.

QueryText: Information Regarding Improved Varieties Of Toria
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the recommended varieties of Rapeseed (Toria)
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the improved varieties of Rapeseed (Toria)?
KccAns: Information Regarding Improved Varieties Of Toria Improved Varieties Of Toria Are Sangam  Tl-15  Th-68
QueryText_normalized: information regarding improved varieties of toria
Primary Answer (Level0): Best growing varieties of Toria (Rapeseed) in Haryana are Sangam, TL 15 and TH 68.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Haryana, some of the best varieties of Toria (rapeseed) for good yield and early harvest are Sangam, TL 15, and TH 68. The 'Sangam' variety is quite popular as it matures early ready in about 85–90 days and gives a good yield of around 10–12 quintals per acre. It is also tolerant to lodging and performs well under irrigated conditions. 'TL 15' is another early-maturing variety, ideal for timely sowing, and gives a yield of around 9–11 quintals per acre along with good oil content. 'TH 68' is suitable for slightly late sowing and gives consistent performance even in limited irrigation conditions, with a yield of about 8–10 quintals per acre.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Context: It doesn't explain why a farmer would choose Toria. The key reason is that it's an extra-early maturing crop (harvested in December) that fits well into specific rotations like Toria-Potato-Wheat.

Missing Quantification: It provides no numbers for yield potential (e.g., 6-8 quintals per acre) or oil content, which are the main factors for profitability.

Primary Answer (Level0): For the Kharif season, varieties such as Bhima Super (180–220 quintals/acre), Bhima Red (160–200 quintals/acre), Bhima Shakti (170–210 quintals/acre), Bhima Kiran (160–190 quintals/acre), and N53 (150–180 quintals/acre) are highly suitable due to their tolerance for purple blotch and their ability. For successful Kharif cultivation, nursery sowing should be done from late May to June, and transplanting should occur between July and mid-August. In the Rabi season, which is more favourable for onion bulb development due to its cool and dry climate, varieties like Hisar-2 (220–250 quintals/acre), Pusa Red (200–240 quintals/acre), and Hisar (210–230 quintals/acre) are recommended. The ideal time for nursery sowing in Rabi is from October to early November, and transplanting in late November to early December.

QueryText: How To Control Black Rust In Barley Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Black Rust disease in Barley crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Black Rust disease in Barley?
KccAns: Spray To Daithain M-45  800 Ml In 250 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control black rust in barley crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Black rust in barley causes black pustules on stems and leaves, leading to weakened plants and reduced grain yield. To control black rust spray Tebuconazole 38.39 SC (176-200 ml/acre) or Azoxystrobin 18.2 + Difenoconazole 11.4 SC (200 ml/acre) or Azoxystrobin 11 + Tebuconazole 18.3 SC (300 ml/acre). Mix any of the one chemical in 200 liters of water and spray on the leaves in one acre area.

Mix any of the one chemical in 200 liters of water and spray on the leaves in one acre area. After doing spray of any chemical pesticide kindly wait for 7-10 days before harvesting so that it becomes safe for human consumption.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Of Blast  In Paddy Crop -
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Blast disease in Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Blast disease in Paddy?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Of Blast  In Paddy Crop -Spray 250 Tillt Or 200 Ml Hinosan  Or 200 Ml Karbendazim  Or 120 Gram Beem 200 Liter Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control of blast in paddy crop -
Primary Answer (Level0): Blast disease causes leaf spots, neck and node infections, leading to reduced yield. To manage blast, use resistant varieties like PR 126 or Pusa Sugandh 5. Practice proper field sanitation by removing infected plant debris. Maintain balanced nitrogen fertilization and avoid excess nitrogen. Spray fungicides like Tricyclazole 75 WP @ 300 g per acre or Carbendazim 50 WP @ 500 g per acre mixed in 200–250 litres of water at the early stages of infection. Repeat spray after 10–15 days if needed. Ensure proper water management to reduce humidity and disease spread.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Blast disease causes leaf spots, neck and node infections, leading to reduced yield. To manage blast, use resistant varieties like Pusa Basmati 1637 and Haryana Basmati No.1. Practice proper field sanitation by removing infected plant debris. Maintain balanced nitrogen fertilization and avoid excess nitrogen. Spray fungicides like Tricyclazole 75 WP @ 120 g per acre or Carbendazim 50 WP @ 120 g per acre mixed in 200–250 litres of water at the early stages of infection. Repeat spray after 10–15 days if needed. Ensure proper water management to reduce humidity and disease spread.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Instead of "PR 126 or Pusa Sugandh 5," the advice should include varieties specifically recommended by regional authorities for their blast resistance, such as "Pusa Basmati 1637" and "Haryana Basmati No. 1".

- The suggested dose of "Tricyclazole 75 WP @ 300 g per acre" is an overdose. The correct foliar spray recommendation is 120 g per acre. Similarly, "Carbendazim 50 WP @ 500 g per acre" is also an overdose; the correct rate is 200 g per acre. Using the original high dosages can lead to crop injury and unnecessary expense.
