QueryText: Information Regarding Control Of Boll Worm In Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bollworm in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bollworm in Cotton?
KccAns: Spray Of Avant  200 Ml In 200 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding control of boll worm in cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Bollworms are major pests of cotton during the kharif season, including Odhan (Sirsa). The three key bollworms are American Bollworm, Pink Bollworm and Spotted Bollworm. Install pheromone traps @ 5–12 per hectare to monitor moth activity. Deep summer ploughing to destroy pupae in soil. Do crop rotation and avoid planting cotton back-to-back. For chemical control (only if pest levels exceed threshold), spray Spinosad 45 SC at 60–75 ml/acre, Chlorantraniliprole (Coragen) 10–12 ml/acre, Emamectin benzoate 5–6 g/acre, or Indoxacarb 20–25 ml/acre, mixed in 70–100 liters water. Rotate chemicals to prevent resistance and spray in early morning or evening for best results.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Bollworms are major pests of cotton during the kharif season in Haryana, including Odhan (Sirsa). The three key bollworms are American Bollworm, Pink Bollworm and Spotted Bollworm. Install pheromone traps @ 5–12 per hectare to monitor moth activity. Deep summer ploughing to destroy pupae in soil. Do crop rotation and avoid planting cotton back-to-back. For chemical control (only if pest levels exceed threshold), spray Spinosad 45 SC at 60–75 ml/acre, Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC 60 ml/acre, Emamectin benzoate 5 SG 80-100 g/acre, or Indoxacarb 20–25 ml/acre, mixed in 70–100 liters water. Rotate chemicals to prevent resistance and spray in early morning or evening for best results. The PHI for Spinosad & Emamectin ranges from 5 days and Chlorantraniliprole & Indoxacarb is 7 days which is essential to ensure safe harvesting and worker health, especially in cotton where manual picking is common.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect Dosages: The per-acre doses for the main insecticides are far too low and incorrect. The standard dose for Emamectin benzoate 5 SG is 80-100 g/acre (not 5-6 g), and for Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC it is 60 ml/acre (not 10-12 ml). Using the suggested low doses would be completely ineffective.

Missing Safety Information: The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period after spraying, which is crucial for worker safety during picking.

For chemical control (only if pest levels exceed threshold), spray Spinosad 45 SC at 60–75 ml/acre, Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC at @ 60 ml/acre, Emamectin benzoate 5 SG at @ 80-90 grams/acre, or Indoxacarb 14.5 CS @ 120 ml/acre, mixed in 70–100 liters of water. Rotate chemicals to prevent resistance, and spray in the early morning or evening for best results. The PHI for Spinosad & Emamectin ranges from 5 days, and Chlorantraniliprole & Indoxacarb is 7 days, which is essential to ensure safe harvesting and worker health, especially in cotton, where manual picking is common.

Primary Answer (Level0): Cauliflower crop in rabi season is most attacked by diamond backmoth, cabbage head borer and aphid. To control diamond backmoth and cabbage head borer spray Fenvalerate 20 EC (120-150 ml/acre) or Emamectin benzoate 5 + Lufenuron 40 WG (24 g/acre). To control aphids spray Dimethoate 30 EC (264 ml/acre) or Fenvalerate 20 EC (120-150 ml/acre). Do not use the same chemical every year always rotate them so to avoid resistance in pests.

For effective control of diamond back moth and cabbage head borer, farmers are advised to spray Emamectin Benzoate 5 SG at the rate of 80 grams per acre or a combination of Emamectin Benzoate 5% + Lufenuron 40% WG at 24 grams per acre. Mix the chemical in 200 liters of water and spray in the early morning or evening when pest activity is high. To control aphids, spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 60 ml per acre or Thiamethoxam 25 WG at 40 grams per acre, mixed in 200 liters of water. Always follow the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) mentioned on the label (usually 7–10 days for Emamectin and 3–7 days for Imidacloprid).

QueryText: Information Regarding To The Sowing Time Of Cauliflower Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the sowing time of Cauliflower crop
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Cauliflower ?
KccAns: To The Sowing Time Of Cauliflower Crop Is May - Jun
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to the sowing time of cauliflower crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Cauliflower is not grown Zaid season because it is cole crop that need optimum temperature between 15-20°C. if you want to grow in zaid season cultivate early maturating varieties like Early Kunwari, Pusa Deepali, or Pant Shubhra. May to June in nurseries and transplant them after 25-30 days. Maintain proper spacing of 45— 30 cm and proper irrigation and give shade during nursery.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Cauliflower is generally not suited for the Zaid season (February to April) due to high temperatures, as it is a cole crop that requires a cool climate with an optimum temperature range of 15–20°C for proper curd formation. Therefore, there is no practical option to grow cauliflower during the Zaid season. However, if you want to cultivate cauliflower in the early Kharif season, choose heat-tolerant, early-maturing varieties such as Early Kunwari, Pusa Deepali, and Pant Shubhra. Which are sown in May–June. Prepare nursery beds in partial shade and sow seeds in May–June. Transplant seedlings after 25–30 days, maintaining a spacing of 45 × 30 cm in the main field. Provide light, frequent irrigation during the nursery stage to prevent heat stress. Timely irrigation is also critical during vegetative growth and curd formation. Under good management practices, these early varieties can yield approximately 80–100 quintals per acre.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Seasonal Information: It incorrectly states that cauliflower is "not grown in Zaid season" and then gives a sowing time of "May to June." May-June nursery sowing is for the early Kharif crop, not a Zaid crop. The actual Zaid crop (sown Feb-Mar) is extremely difficult but possible with specific varieties. The answer confuses the seasons.

Missing Key Details: To be a useful guide, it must provide the yield potential per acre for the varieties it mentions.

QueryText: How To Control Weed Bathua In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Bathua (Chenopodium album) in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Bathua (Chenopodium album) in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray Of 2-4D Sodium Salt 250G 200Lit Of Waterper Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control weed bathua in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Chenopodium album (Bathua) in wheat competes aggressively for nutrients and light, leading to reduced crop growth and lower yields if not controlled early. For controlling Chenopodium album (Bathua) in wheat spray Dicamba 48 SL (200ml/acre) or Flumioxazin 50 SC (100 ml/acre) or Metribuzin 70 WP (250 g/acre). Mix any one of the herbicide in 200 liters of water and spray on the weed after 30-35 days of sowing wheat.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Chenopodium album (Bathua) is a common and aggressive broadleaf weed in wheat that competes for nutrients, sunlight, and space, leading to weaker crop growth and lower yields if not controlled on time. For effective control in Haryana, farmers are advised to spray Metsulfuron-methyl 10% + Carfentrazone-ethyl 20% WG at 40 grams per acre, or 2,4-D Amine Salt 58% SL at 400 ml per acre, depending on weed type and crop stage. Mix any one of these herbicides in 200 litres of water and spray after 30–35 days of sowing, when Bathua and other broadleaf weeds are actively growing.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Sub-optimal Recommendation: While the chemicals work, the most widely used, effective, and often crop-safer herbicides for broadleaf weeds like Bathua in Haryana are combinations like Metsulfuron + Carfentrazone or simply 2,4-D. Metribuzin can cause sensitivity issues in some wheat varieties.

Missing Integrated Advice: An expert answer would also mention that a single spray of a broad-spectrum herbicide that controls both broadleaf and grassy weeds is the most efficient strategy for most farmers.

If your priority is to harvest early to prepare your field for the next wheat crop on time, then the early-maturing Pusa Basmati 1509 is the perfect variety for you. For a smart, low-risk option, consider Pusa Basmati 1718, which is an improved version of 1121 with in-built resistance to Bacterial Blight disease. This special trait can save you â‚¹2000-2500 per acre on sprays, making it a very profitable choice.

Primary Answer (Level0): Planting the right guava is a long-term investment, so it's best to focus on the top varieties that give great fruit and yield. Lucknow-49, which everyone calls Sardar, is a fantastic choice because its fruit is sweet with fewer seeds and has a thick flesh, often fetching a premium price. A well-managed mature orchard of Sardar can easily yield 100-120 quintals of fruit per acre. Another excellent variety developed right here is Hisar Safeda, which is known for its high-quality round fruit and also has a great yield potential of 100-120 quintals per acre from a mature orchard, which means very high income per acre.

QueryText: Information Regarding To Improved Varieties Of Maize
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What are the improved varieties of Maize?

QueryText_normalized: information regarding to improved varieties of maize
Primary Answer (Level0): The right maize variety for your farm really depends on what you need it for. If you're looking for a high grain yield to sell in the market, single-cross hybrids like HM-5 or HM-11 are a great bet, with a strong yield potential of 25-30 quintals per acre. But if your main purpose is green fodder for your animals, then the best choice is the fodder-specific variety J-1006, which gives a very high tonnage of around 180-200 quintals of green fodder per acre. For families wanting better nutrition from their crop, consider HQPM-1, a Quality Protein Maize variety that offers a good grain yield of 24-26 quintals per acre along with its higher protein content.

AICMIP/ICAR Hybrid List: https://aicmip.naarm.org.in/Documents/Hybrids%20of%20maize%20released-1.pdf

If your main purpose is green fodder for your animals, then the best choice is the fodder-specific variety J-1006, which gives very high tonnage. QueryText: Information Regarding Improved Varities Of Sugarcane Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the recommended improved varieties of the Sugarcane crop
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the suitable varieties of Sugarcane?
KccAns: Improved Varities Of Sugarcane Crop :- Co7717Coh99Cos8436
QueryText_normalized: information regarding improved varities of sugarcane crop
Primary Answer (Level0): COJ 64, COH 56, and COH 92 are early maturing sugarcane varieties, suitable for early harvesting COH 99, CO 7717, CoS 8436, and CoH 119 are medium maturing varieties among them, COH 99 is drought-tolerant and is recommended for cultivation. On the other side Co 1148, CoH 35 (Haryana 35), CoS 767, and COH 110 are late maturing varieties, ideal for late sowing conditions.
Source [Name and Link]: Sugarcane Crop Farming Punjab | Apni Kheti
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Sugarcane varieties in Haryana can be classified based on maturity period. Early maturing varieties such as COJ 64, COH 56, and COH 92 are suitable for early harvesting and can yield around 30–35 tonnes per acre under good management. Medium maturing varieties include COH 99, CO 7717, CoS 8436, and COH 119. Among them, COH 99 is drought-tolerant and recommended widely across Haryana; gives yield around 35–40 tonnes per acre. For late maturing conditions, Co 1148, CoH 35 (Haryana 35), CoS 767, and COH 110 are ideal, especially where sowing is delayed; these can yield up to 40–45 tonnes per acre. Selecting the right variety based on sowing time, water availability, and harvest planning helps maximize cane yield and sugar recovery.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Yield Quantification: The advice would be complete if it included the yield potential in tonnes or quintals per acre for the key recommended varieties (e.g., CoH 119 can yield 35-40 tonnes per acre), allowing a farmer to compare them.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Weeds In Barley Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control weeds in Barley crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control weeds in Barley?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Weeds In Barley Crop Spray 24-D  500 Ml In 200 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control weeds in barley crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Common broadleaf weeds in barley, such as Bathua, Senji/Methi, and Hirankhuri, can be controlled by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl @ 8 g/acre around 25-30 days after sowing. For grass weeds like Madusi (Phalaris minor) and Wild oat, use herbicides such Axial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) @ 400 ml/acre, or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron-methyl 3% + Iodosulfuron-methyl sodium 0.6% WG) @ 160 g/acre for early weed control, apply a pre-emergence herbicide like Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) @ 1.3 liters/acre either just before or within 2 days of sowing.
Source [Name and Link]: Barley | Barley Crop Farming | Apni Kheti
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Common broadleaf weeds in barley, such as Bathua, Senji (Methi), and Hirankhuri, can be effectively controlled by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl at 8 g per acre around 25–30 days after sowing. For grass weeds like Madusi (Phalaris minor) and Wild oat, post-emergence herbicides such as Axial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) at 400 ml per acre or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron-methyl 3% + Iodosulfuron-methyl sodium 0.6% WG) at 160 g per acre are recommended. For early weed control, apply a pre-emergence herbicide like Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) at 1.3 liters per acre either just before or within two days of sowing. It is important to rotate herbicides with different modes of action each year.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Context of Herbicide Resistance: The advice would be even stronger if it mentioned the importance of rotating herbicides with different modes of action over the years. This is a crucial strategy to prevent weeds like Madusi (Phalaris minor) from developing resistance, a major problem in the region.

QueryText: Information Regarding Weed Control Of  Wheat
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding weed control in Wheat
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control weeds in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray To Topic  160 Gm In 200 Litres Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding weed control of wheat
Primary Answer (Level0): Common broadleaf weeds like Bathua ,Senji/Methi and Hirankhuri can be controlled by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl @ 8 g/acre around 25-30 days after sowing.For grass weeds such as Madusi and Wild oat use herbicides like Topik (Clodinafop-propargyl 15% WP) @ 160 g/acre orAxial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) @ 400 ml/acre or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron-methyl 3% + Iodosulfuron-methyl sodium 0.6% WG) @ 160 g/acre only after confirming the presence of grass weeds, around 30-35 days after sowing, because it may harm the main crop. For early weed control, apply a pre-emergence herbicide like Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) @ 1.3 liters/acre, either within 2 days of sowing or just before sowing.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Common broadleaf weeds in wheat such as Bathua, Senji/Methi, and Hirankhuri can be effectively controlled by spraying Metsulfuron-methyl @ 8 g/acre around 25–30 days after sowing. For grass weeds like Phalaris minor (Madusi) and Wild oat, use Topik (Clodinafop-propargyl 15% WP) @ 160 g/acre, Axial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) @ 400 ml/acre, or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron + Iodosulfuron) @ 160 g/acre, but only after confirming the presence of grass weeds. These post-emergence herbicides should be applied at the correct crop and weed stage, typically between 30–35 days after sowing, when weeds are at the 2–4 leaf stage. For early-season weed control, apply a pre-emergence herbicide like Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) @ 1.3 liters/acre, either just before or within 2 days of sowing. Integrated use of these herbicides, along with timely application, ensures effective weed control while minimizing crop damage..

QueryText: How To Control Of Flower Droping In Guava
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control flower dropping in Guava?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower dropping in Guava?
KccAns: Spray Of Planofix 1 Ml In 45 Liter Water
QueryText_normalized: how to control of flower droping in guava
Primary Answer (Level0): Control Measures to Reduce Flower Drop at nutritional stage is apply micronutrients at pre flowering, before flowering stages, and spray hormonal sprays like NAA (Naphthalene Acetic Acid) - 10â€“20 ppm (1â€“2 ml/10L water),Planofix - 1 ml/L water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Guava flower dropping during the Rabi season (winter months) in Haryana can be caused by a combination of factors, including environmental conditions, nutritional deficiencies, and pest or disease attacks. Applying organic or slow-release fertilizers helps maintain optimal nutrient levels and enhances fruit set. Drip irrigation can improve water usage and increase fruit size and number. Use methyl eugenol lure traps and bait sprays. apply Growth Regulator Use - Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 20 ppm (2 ml per 100 L) Spray at flower bud initiation and early bloom to reduce flower drop.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- The answer recommends a brand name, "Planofix".
To maintain neutrality, all brand names must be avoided. The generic chemical name for the active ingredient in Planofix is Alpha Naphthyl Acetic Acid , which is a type of NAA already mentioned. The brand name should be removed.   

- The sentence structure is grammatically incorrect and confusing.
The answer should be rewritten into clear, simple sentences. For example: "To reduce flower drop, apply micronutrients before the flowering stage. Additionally, use a hormonal spray of Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) at a concentration of 10–20 ppm..."

- "Droping" should be corrected to "Dropping".

Applying organic or slow-release fertilizers helps maintain optimal nutrient levels and enhances fruit set. Drip irrigation can improve water usage and increase fruit size and number. Use methyl eugenol lure traps and bait sprays. apply Growth Regulator Use - Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 20 ppm (2 ml per 100 L) Spray at flower bud initiation and early bloom to reduce flower drop.
Comment (Reviewer2): Methyl eugenol traps are for fruit flies, not directly for flower drop, though they help indirectly. Mention it clearly
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Guava flower dropping during the Rabi season (winter months) can be caused by a combination of factors, including environmental conditions, nutritional deficiencies, and pest or disease attacks. Applying organic or slow-release fertilizers helps maintain optimal nutrient levels and enhances fruit set. Drip irrigation improves water use efficiency and increases both fruit size and number. To reduce flower drop Pest management: Use methyl eugenol lure traps (for fruit fly management) and bait sprays. Growth regulator: Apply Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 20 ppm (2 ml per 100 L of water) at flower bud initiation and early bloom stages.

To reduce flower drop Pest management: Use methyl eugenol lure traps (for fruit fly management) and bait sprays. Growth regulator: Apply Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 20 ppm (2 ml per 100 L of water) at flower bud initiation and early bloom stages.
Final Answer: Guava flower dropping during the Rabi season (winter months) can be caused by a combination of factors, including environmental conditions, nutritional deficiencies, and pest or disease attacks. Applying organic or slow-release fertilizers helps maintain optimal nutrient levels and enhances fruit set. Drip irrigation improves water use efficiency and increases both fruit size and number. To reduce flower drop Pest management: Use methyl eugenol lure traps (for fruit fly management) and bait sprays. Growth regulator: Apply Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 20 ppm (2 ml per 100 L of water) at flower bud initiation and early bloom stages.

QueryText: Information Regarding The Control Of Wild Oats In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Wild Oats in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Wild Oats in Wheat crop?
KccAns: I Told The Kisan Spray 160 Grmof Topik In 200 Litres Of Wateracrespray 30-35 Day After Sowing
QueryText_normalized: information regarding the control of wild oats in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Wild oats have become very difficult to control with isoproturon because they have developed resistance. For effective control, spray Clodinafop-propargyl 15% WP @ 160 g per acre mixi in 35–50 litres of water, by using a fan type nozzle for evenly spray. Control them early before they spread too much. The right time to spray is 30–35 days after sowing, when the wild oat plants are 2–3 inches tall.  Spray in the morning when the wind is low. Make sure the soil has some moisture, but do not spray on dry soil. Wild oats look like wheat in early stage, so check properly before spraying. Wear hand gloves and wash hands after spraying. This will help protect your wheat crop and give better yield.

QueryText: Control Of Fruit Borer In Okra
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Fruit Borer in Okra?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Fruit Borer in Okra?
KccAns: Spray Of Malathion  400 Ml In 200 Liters Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of fruit borer in okra
Primary Answer (Level0): Controlling fruit borer in okra is important for successful crop growth, as it can cause significant damage to shoots, buds, and fruits. It makes holes in okra and damages shoots and reduces yield. To control fruit borer in Okra,  remove and destroy infested shoots and fruits, and install pheromone traps(5-6 per acre) to reduce the population. If the infestation is severe, rotate insecticide spray of Emamectin Benzoate 5 SG @ 80 grams per acre in 200 litres of water or Spinosad 45 SC @ 80-100 ml per acre in 200 litres of water to prevent fruit borer resistance.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Controlling fruit borer in okra is important for successful crop growth, as it can cause significant damage to shoots, buds, and fruits. It makes holes in okra and damages shoots and reduces yield. To control fruit borer in Okra, an integrated pest management approach combining cultural, mechanical, biological, and chemical measures is recommended. Remove and destroy infested shoots and fruits by clipping/nipping off the shoots below the entrance hole, collect and destroy affected fruits, and install pheromone traps(5-6 per acre) to reduce population. Release Trichogramma chilonis @ 45000 per acre, conserve ladybird beetles, lacewings, king crow, fire ants, ground beetles, spray Beauveria bassiana 1% WP @ 1500-2000 grams in 160-200 litres of water/acre and spray azadirachtin 0.03% (300 ppm) neem oil-based WSP @ 1000-2000 ml in 200-400 liters of water/acre. If the infestation is severe, rotate insecticide spray of Emamectin Benzoate 5 SG @ 80 grams per acre in 200 litres of water or Spinosad 45 SC @ 80-100 ml per acre in 200 litres of water, or Chloranthraniliprole 18.5% SC @ 50 ml in 200 litres of water/acre to prevent fruit borer resistance. For frequently harvested vegetables like okra, it is necessary to maintain pre pre-harvest interval ( PHI) of 5 days for Emamectin Benzoate and 3-4 days for Spinosad.
Comment (Reviewer1): Critical Safety Omission: The answer is unsafe because it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period. For a frequently picked vegetable like okra, this is essential. The PHI is 5 days for Emamectin Benzoate and 3-4 days for Spinosad.

QueryText: Control Of Weeds In Bajra
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control weeds in Pearl millet (Bajra)?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control weeds in Pearl Millet (Bajra)?
KccAns: Spray Of Etrazene  400 Gm In 250 Liters Of Water Per Acre After Sowing
QueryText_normalized: control of weeds in bajra
Primary Answer (Level0): Controlling weeds in bajra is very important because weeds can compete for light water and nutrient with main crop an can be host for many insects pest which can damage your crop severely and reduce your yield. The first 25-35 days are after sowing is very critical for controlling weeds. You can control weeds by using mulching or you can do 2 hand weeding First weeding 15-20 days after sowing (DAS) and Second weeding or hoeing 30-35 DAS. You can use pre-emergence herbicide like Atrazine 50% WP @ 500 g/acre in 200 liters of water within 2 days of sowing. For post-emergence, use 2,4-D Sodium Salt 80% WP @ 250 g/acre in 200 liters of water at 20â€“25 DAS if needed.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Controlling weeds in bajra is very important because weeds can compete for light, water, and nutrients with the main crop and can host many insect pests, which can damage your crop severely and reduce your yield. The first 25-35 days after sowing are very critical for controlling weeds. You can control weeds by using mulch, or you can do weeding. First weeding 15-20 days after sowing (DAS) and Second weeding or hoeing 30-35 DAS. You can use a pre-emergence herbicide like Atrazine 50% WP @ 200-250 g/acre in 200 litres of water within 2 days of sowing. For post-emergence, use 2,4-D Sodium Salt 80% WP @ 250 g/acre in 200 litres of water at 20–25 DAS for broadleaf weeds. Do not use it regularly or in excess; use only if needed.
Comment (Reviewer1):
-	Reduce the Atrazine 50% WP dose to 200â€“250g per acre (not 500g) mixed in 200 litres of water, applied within 2â€“3 days after sowing.
Recommended pre-emergence rate for bajra is 0.5kg/ha (~200g/acre) to avoid crop injury and achieve effective grass and broadleaf control.

-	Clarify that the 2,4-D Sodium Salt 80% WP dose of 250g per acre in 200 litres water at 20â€“25 DAS is only for broadleaf weed escapes; do not use it routinely if grass weeds dominate.
Overuse of 2,4-D can harm the crop; it should target broadleaf weeds only at the critical timing.

-	change â€œan can be hostâ€ to â€œand can host.â€

QueryText: Information Regarding Variety Of Coriander
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the recommended varieties of Coriander
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What are the recommended varieties of Coriander?
KccAns: Hisar Sugandh
QueryText_normalized: information regarding variety of coriander
Primary Answer (Level0): Coriander thrives in cooler temperature, and it is well suited for Rabi season crop, However, it can also be grown for leaf purposes during the Kharif season (monsoon season, June-July) in Haryana but higher temperatures and humidity during the Kharif season can lead to premature bolting (flowering) and reduced foliage development. Haryana specific varieties are Hisar Sugandh (DH-36), Hisar Anand- 110-120 days, Hisar Surbhi - 100-110 days, and Rajendra Swati 110 days While it's a mid-season variety, its adaptability to Haryana's climate might make it a viable option for Kharif season cultivation in Rohtak district in Haryana.

QueryText: Information Regarding Sowing Time Of Coriander
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the sowing time of Coriander
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Coriander?
KccAns: Mid Sept -December
QueryText_normalized: information regarding sowing time of coriander
Primary Answer (Level0): Coriander usually follows Rabi season in Haryana .Sowing is mostly done during the mid of October to mid of November.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
Coriander usually follows Rabi season in Haryana .Sowing is mostly done during the mid of October to mid of November.
Some of the varieties of the commonly grown are Hisar Sugandh highly recommended for its aroma and good seed yield. RCr-41 which is high yield, medium duration, good aroma and Rajendra Swathi known for its high yielding, aromatic, suitable for both leaf and seed.
Seed rate for of Coriander in Haryana depends on the purpose of coriander. If it is for green leaf production  12–15 kg/acre and for Grain (Seed) Production it is 8–10 kg/acre.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Variety Information: It fails to recommend any improved, high-yielding coriander varieties suitable for Haryana, such as Hisar Sugandh.

Seed rate for of Coriander in Haryana depends on the purpose of coriander. If it is for green leaf production  12–15 kg/acre and for Grain (Seed) Production it is 8–10 kg/acre.

QueryText: How To Control Damping Of Seedling In Paddy Nursery
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control damping-off disease in Paddy seedlings in the nursery?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Damping-off disease in Paddy seedlings in the nursery?
KccAns: Spray To Vavistan  25 Gm In 25 Litre Of Water Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control damping of seedling in paddy nursery
Primary Answer (Level0): Damping off is a serious fungal disease affecting rice seedlings, especially in wet, humid conditions during nursery raising. Due to this, seedlings are rotted at the base, fall over, and wet, brown patches are seen in the nursery. To control this use clean healthy seeds, treat rice seed with Carbendazim 50 WP or Thiram @ 2.5 gram per kg of seed, or you can use Trichoderma viride@ 10 gram per kg seed as bio agent option, raise nursey beds slightly above the ground to prevent water stagnation, irrigate lightly and only when needed, drench nursery with Carbendazim 50 WP @ 1 gram per litre of water or Mancozeb 75 WP @ 2-2.5 gram per litre of water if damping off appears and apply 2-3 times at 5-7 days interval.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Damping off is a serious fungal disease affecting rice seedlings, especially in wet, humid conditions during nursery raising. Due to this, seedlings are rotted at the base, fall over, and wet, brown patches are seen in the nursery. To control this, use clean, healthy seeds; treat rice seed with Carbendazim 50 WP or Thiram @ 2.5 grams per kg of seed, or you can use Trichoderma viride at 10 grams per kg of seed as a bioagent option; raise nursery beds slightly above the ground to prevent water stagnation; irrigate lightly and only when needed; drench the nursery with Copper Oxychloride @ 2-3 g/litre of water or Mancozeb 75 WP @ 2-2.5 grams per litre of water if damping-off appears, and apply 2-3 times at 5-7 day intervals.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Modern Alternatives: A better recommendation for seed treatment would be Thiram 75% WS at 2.5 g/kg seed. For drenching, a safer and effective option is Copper Oxychloride at 2-3 g/litre of water.

QueryText: Information Regarding Improved Varities Of Desi Cotton

Primary Answer (Level0): Desi cotton is a smart choice as its input cost is lower. HD 123 is a reliable performer. A newer variety, HD 432, is excellent. It has better staple length, which means you get a better price, and it has a high ginning outturn of around 38-40%, meaning more cotton and less waste per quintal. Its natural tolerance to pests can save you at least 2-3 insecticide sprays compared to hybrid cotton.

QueryText: Information Regarding Sowing Time Of Lentil
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding sowing time of Lentil
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the best time for sowing Lentil?
KccAns: Sowing Time Of Lentil: 1 Nav-7 Dec
QueryText_normalized: information regarding sowing time of lentil
Primary Answer (Level0): Do sowing of lentil in rainfed areas during second fortnight of October and in irrigated areas do sowing during first fortnight of November.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Do sowing of lentil in rainfed areas during second fortnight of October and in irrigated areas do sowing during first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important, to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Variety Information: The advice is not actionable without recommending specific, high-yielding lentil varieties that are suitable for Haryana's conditions, such as Sapna or Garima.

Missing Context: It fails to explain why timely sowing is important, which is to ensure the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Do sowing of lentil in rainfed areas during second fortnight of October and in irrigated areas do sowing during first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important, to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Comment (Reviewer2): Note differing maturity varieties (e.g., Pusa 833, Pusa 911) may shift sowing dates slightly.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Do sowing of Lentil in rainfed areas during second fortnight of October and in irrigated areas do sowing during first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important, to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): Do sowing of Lentil in rainfed areas during second fortnight of October and in irrigated areas do sowing during first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important, to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): Do sowing of lentils in rainfed areas during the second fortnight of October, and in irrigated areas do sowing during the first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.
Final Answer: Do sowing of lentils in rainfed areas during the second fortnight of October, and in irrigated areas do sowing during the first fortnight of November. Timely sowing is important to ensure that the crop completes its lifecycle before the onset of high temperatures in March, which can severely reduce grain size and yield.

QueryText: How To Control Downy Mildew In Bottle Gourd

QueryText_normalized: how to control downy mildew in bottle gourd
Primary Answer (Level0): Downy mildew can wipe out your profits in a week. To control it, a spray of a combination fungicide like Metalaxyl + Mancozeb is the best solution. Use 2 grams per litre of water. A single spray for one acre will cost you roughly around 400-500. This small investment protects your entire potential harvest, which could be worth thousands.

QueryText: How To Control Downey Mildew In Cauliflower Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Downy Mildew in Cauliflower crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Downy Mildew in Cauliflower crop?
KccAns: Spray To Mancozeb  400 Gm In 200 Liter Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control downey mildew in cauliflower crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Downy mildew in cauliflower causes yellow patches on upper leaf surfaces and white fungal growth underneath, leading to poor head formation. For controlling downy mildew in cauliflower spray Mancozeb 75 WP (2.5 g/l) or Azoxystrobin 4.8 + Chlorothalonil 40 SC (3ml/l).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Downy mildew in cauliflower causes yellow patches on upper leaf surfaces and white fungal growth underneath, leading to poor head formation. For controlling downy mildew in cauliflower spray Mancozeb 75 WP (2.5 g/l) or Azoxystrobin 4.8 + Chlorothalonil 40 SC (3ml/l). After using any of these fungicides, it is advised to wait for atleast 7 days before doing harvesting, so that the chemical residue breaks down and the produce remains safe for consumption.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critical Safety Omission: The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI). For a vegetable like cauliflower, this is essential. For example, the PHI for Mancozeb is 7-10 days.

Impractical Dosages: Doses are given per litre. A professional answer must provide the standard per-acre rate (e.g., Mancozeb 75% WP at 500-600 grams per acre) for proper spray planning.

QueryText: How To Control Downy Mildew  In Muskmelon
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Downy Mildew in Muskmelon?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Downy Mildew in Muskmelon?
KccAns: Spray 500 Gm Blitox In 200 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control downy mildew in muskmelon
Primary Answer (Level0): Downy mildew in muskmelon causes yellow angular spots on the upper leaf surface, grayish purple fungal growth on the lower leaf surface, and reduces fruit quality and yield. To control downy mildew in muskmelon, avoid planting muskmelons or other cucurbits(cucumber, bottle gourd) in same field year after year and rotate with legumes or vegetables, grow muskmelon in well-drained soil with good sunlight exposure, avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness, and spray protective fungicides i.e. Mancozeb 75 WP @ 600-800 gram per acre mixed in 200 litres of water before disease appears or at the first sign of infection at 7-12 days interval or spray combination of Metalaxyl 8+ Mancozeb 64 WP @500-800 gram per acre mixed with 200-250litres of water and spray at every 7-10 days interval depending on disease pressure.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Downy mildew in muskmelon causes yellow angular spots on the upper leaf surface, grayish-purple fungal growth on the lower leaf surface, and reduced fruit quality and yield. To control downy mildew in muskmelon, avoid planting muskmelons or other cucurbits (cucumber, bottle gourd) in the same field year after year and rotate with legumes or vegetables, grow muskmelon in well-drained soil with good sunlight exposure, avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness, and spray protective fungicides, i.e., Mancozeb 75 WP @ 600-800 grams per acre mixed in 200 litres of water, before the disease appears or at the first sign of infection at 7-12 day intervals, or spray a combination of Metalaxyl 8% + Mancozeb 64% WP @ 500-800 grams per acre mixed with 200-250 litres of water and spray at every 7-10 day interval depending on disease pressure. The PHI (pre-harvest interval) period of mancozeb is 7 days, and for metalaxyl + mancozeb, it is 10-14 days.
Comment (Reviewer1): Critical Safety Omission: The advice is unsafe because it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period after spraying. QueryText: Planting Time Of Grape
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is the best planting time for Grapes?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the best planting time for grapes?
KccAns: July
QueryText_normalized: planting time of grape
Primary Answer (Level0): Due to high temperature in Zaid season Grapes are not recommended to grow in Zaid season because high temperature may lead to fungal infection how ever you planned to cultivate grapes go for rabi season from December-February.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Grapes are not recommended for planting during the Zaid season in Haryana due to extreme summer heat, which can cause severe heat stress, poor establishment, and high mortality of young vines. If you are planning to cultivate grapes, the ideal time for planting is during the Rabi season, specifically in the January–February window, after the risk of winter frost has subsided. This timing ensures better vine survival and healthier growth under more favorable climatic conditions.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Planting Time: It recommends planting in "December-February." Planting in December is not recommended as the new saplings can be damaged by severe winter frost. The ideal and safe window for planting new grapevines in Haryana is January-February, after the peak frost period has passed.

Confusing Reasoning: It incorrectly links high temperature to fungal infection. The primary reason to avoid summer planting is the extreme heat stress, which leads to high mortality in new plants.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Weeds In Arhar Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding how to control weeds in Arhar (Pigeon pea) crop
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can weeds be effectively managed in the arhar (pigeon pea) crop?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Weeds In Arhar Crop No Chemical Used Only Hand Hoeing
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control weeds in arhar crop
Primary Answer (Level0): During the initial stages of weed growth removal of weeds using hand hoeing after 20 days of sowing and the second weeding has to be done on 45 days after sowing. In later stages Imazethapyr 10% SL400 ml in 200 liters of water for an acre. Ensure not to mix fertilizers and Weedicides in the same tank.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
To prevent the weed growth make sure to plough the field deeply to destroy any weed seeds. Application of Pendimethalin Pendimethalin 30% EC 1 liter mixed with 200 liters of water should be sprayed within 1-2 days after sowing before crop and weed emergence.

During the initial stages of weed growth removal of weeds using hand hoeing after 20 days of sowing and the second weeding has to be done on 45 days after sowing. After 15-20 days of sowing spraying of  Imazethapyr 10% SL400 ml in 200 liters of water for an acre should be carried out. 

 Ensure not to mix fertilizers and Weedicides in the same tank.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Pre-emergence Strategy: It completely omits the standard and most effective practice, which is to apply a pre-emergence herbicide like Pendimethalin 30 EC at a dose of 1 litre per acre within 2 days of sowing. This step prevents weeds from growing in the first place.

Vague Timing: The advice for the Imazethapyr spray ("In later stages") is too vague. An expert must specify the correct timing, which is 15-20 days after sowing, when weeds are small and easy to control.

Ensure not to mix fertilizers and Weedicides in the same tank.
Comment (Reviewer2): Imazethapyr application stated “15–20 DAS” but optimum post-emergence is 20–25 DAS when weeds are at 2–3 leaf stage.

QueryText: How To Control Early Blight In Chilli
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Early Blight in Chilli?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Early Blight in chilli crop?
KccAns: Spray 400 Gm M-45 In 200 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control early blight in chilli
Primary Answer (Level0): Early blight in chilli Is a common disease where It appeared in humid weather during July-September for controlling it you can grow resistant varieties like Pusa Jwala which can give approx. yield upto 12-15 q/acre or CH-27 it is also high demanding variety which gives yield upto 10-12 q/acre also you can Spray Mancozeb @2.5g/lit. or Neem oil 5ml/lit. at 10-days of intervals when brown target-like spots appear on leaves. also Remove the infected plant debris.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Early blight in chili It is a common disease that appears in humid weather during July-September. To control it, you can grow resistant varieties like CH-1, which gives a yield of up to 10-13 q/acre; Arka Niharika, which can give an approximate yield of up to 12-15 q/acre; or Pusa Jwala and CH-27 It is also a high-demand variety, which gives a yield of up to 10-12 q/acre and also controls leaf curl virus and fungal disease. You can use (7-10 days of interval) Mancozeb at 250-350 gm/acre. or Neem oil at 300 ml/acre at 10-day intervals. Also, remove the infected plant debris.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Variety Information: It incorrectly lists Pusa Jwala and CH-27 as resistant to Early Blight. These varieties are known for resistance to viruses (like Leaf Curl), not specifically this fungal disease. This is misleading information.

Impractical Dosage: The dose for Mancozeb is given per litre, which is not practical. An expert answer must provide the per-acre rate (e.g., 600-800 grams per acre).

Missing Safety Information: The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI), which is 7-10 days for Mancozeb on chillies.

QueryText: Control Of Early Blight In Tomato
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Early Blight in Tomato?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Early Blight in Tomato?
KccAns: Soray Of Daithane M 45  400 Gm In 200 Liters Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of early blight in tomato
Primary Answer (Level0): Early blight in tomato is a common fungal disease, especially during humid or wet weather. It causes show brown spots on older leaves with yellowing and can reduce yield if not controlled early. To manage it, spray Mancozeb 75% WP at 600–800 g per acre in 200 litres of water every 7–10 days. For better control, use Azoxystrobin 11%  and Tebuconazole 18.3% SC at 300 ml per acre. Rotate these chemicals to avoid resistance. Always start spraying at first symptom as see and avoid over irrigation. Use disease-free seeds and avoid planting tomato repeatedly in the same land. Use resistant varieties like Arka Rakshak, US 440, or Swarna Lalima, which are suitable for Haryana. Remove and burn infected leaves to stop spread. Follow label instructions and wear hand gloves and musk while spraying for safety protection.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Early blight in tomato is a common fungal disease in Haryana, especially during humid or wet weather. It causes brown spots on older leaves with yellowing and can reduce yield if not controlled early. To manage it, spray Mancozeb 75% WP @ 600 g per acre in 200 litres of water every 7–10 days. In case of severe infection, increase dose to 800 g per acre. For better control, use Azoxystrobin 11% + Tebuconazole 18.3% SC @ 300 ml per acre. Rotate these chemicals to avoid resistance. Always start spraying at first symptoms and avoid over irrigation. Use disease-free seeds and avoid planting tomato repeatedly in the same land. Use resistant varieties like Arka Rakshak or Swarna Lalima, which are suitable for Haryana. (US 440 is a private hybrid; confirm local recommendation before use.) Remove and burn infected leaves to stop spread. Follow label instructions and wear hand gloves and mask while spraying for safety. The most important rule for safety is the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI): you must wait 7-10 days after spraying Mancozeb and 5-7 days after the systemic spray before harvesting any tomatoes.

The most important rule for safety is the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI): you must wait 7-10 days after spraying Mancozeb and 5-7 days after the systemic spray before harvesting any tomatoes.

QueryText: How Control Weed In Garlic

QueryText: Information Regarding The Subcidy On Rotavater
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the subsidy on Rotavator
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the subsidy on Rotavator
KccAns: I Told The Kisan The Subcidy On Rotavater Is 25Please Contect Ado Concerd Block
QueryText_normalized: information regarding the subcidy on rotavater
Primary Answer (Level0): Farmers can get 40% to 50% subsidy on rotavator under schemes like PM Kisan (Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi) or SMAM (Sub-Mission on Agricultural Mechanization). To apply, visit the local agriculture office or CSC (Common Service Centre) with your following documents like Aadhaar card, land papers, bank passbook, and dealer quotation. Apply early, as subsidy is limited and given on first-come-first-serve basis. In Hisar or Haryana, you can check the Agri -Haryana portal for updates.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Farmers in Haryana can get a  40% subsidy on rotavator under the SMAM (Sub-Mission on Agricultural Mechanization) and CRM (Crop Residue Management) schemes.  In Haryana, Scheduled Caste, Tribe, and Other Backward farmers are eligible for 50% subsidy under the state mechanization plan. To apply, farmers must visit their local Agriculture Office or Common Service Centre (CSC) and submit key documents like Aadhaar card, land ownership papers, bank passbook. Applications must be submitted online through the MeRi Fasal–Mera Byora (MFMB) portal at www.agriharyana.gov.in. Selection is made by the District Level Executive Committee (DLEC) through a lottery system, not on a first-come-first-serve basis. After machine purchase, farmers must upload the bill and geotagged photo for physical verification to get the subsidy. PM-Kisan is not a machinery subsidy scheme; it is a direct income support scheme. Farmers are advised to apply early with all correct documents to increase the chances of approval.

Haryana provides 40% for all farmers and an enhanced 50% for Scheduled Caste/Tribe and other backward groups under its Implement Bank/SMAM scheme.

- Omit first-come-first-served clause: Selection is by draw of lots at DLEC, not simply first-apply basis.
Haryana uses district lot draw for fair allocation, as per scheme guidelines.

- Expand portal reference: Specify the MeRi Fasalâ€“Mera Byora (MFMB) portal at agriharyana.gov.in, not â€œAgri-Haryana portal.â€

QueryText: Information Regarding Fertilizer Dose In Ber
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding fertilizer dose in Ber
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended fertilizer dose for ber orchards?
KccAns: Fertilizer Dose In Ber :- 25 Kg Fym 800 Gm Urea 1200 Gm Single Super Phasfet Per Plant
QueryText_normalized: information regarding fertilizer dose in ber
Primary Answer (Level0): Fertilizer application in Ber depends on the plant age . For young plants up to 3 years apply 10-20 kg of farmyard manure (FYM), 100-300 g of nitrogen (N), 50-150 g of phosphorus (P205…), and 50-150 g of potassium (K2O) per plant per year. And for mature plants above 4 years increase the dose to 30-50 kg FYM, 500-750 g nitrogen, 250-300 g phosphorus, and 250-300 g potassium per plant annually.
Source [Name and Link]: Ber Information | Ber Farming in Haryana https://agritech.tnau.ac.in/horticulture/horti_fruits_ber.html
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Fertilizer application in Ber should be adjusted based on the plant’s age to ensure optimal growth and fruiting. For young plants up to 3 years old, apply 10–20 kg of well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) along with 100–300 g of nitrogen (N), 50–150 g of phosphorus (P₂O₅), and 50–150 g of potassium (K₂O) per plant annually. For mature plants above 4 years, increase the dose to 30–50 kg FYM, 500–750 g nitrogen, 250–300 g phosphorus, and 250–300 g potassium per plant per year. In terms of 1.1 kg of Urea, 1.5 kg of Single Super Phosphate (SSP), 400 g of Muriate of Potash (MOP).

QueryText: Information Regarding Fertilizer Dose In Grape
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding fertilizer dose in Grapes
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the fertilizer schedule for grapes?
KccAns: Urea 750 Gm Ssp 750 Gm
QueryText_normalized: information regarding fertilizer dose in grape
Primary Answer (Level0): Fertilizers in grapes should be given according to the age of the plant, in young plants up to 2 years apply 10-15 kg of well-rotted farmyard manure, 25-30 grams of nitrogen, 20-25 grams of phosphorus, and 25-30 grams of potassium for mature plants up to 3 years apply 30-40 kg FYM, 100-120 grams nitrogen, 50-60 grams phosphorus, and 100-120 grams potassium. Nitrogen should be given in three splits first before sprouting, second after sprouting, and the third during berry growth. FYM, Potassium, Phosphorous should be applied before pruning.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Fertilizer application in grapes should be based on the plant’s age and local practices such as the ‘Bahar’ flowering system commonly followed in Haryana. For young plants up to 2 years, apply 10–15 kg of well-rotted farmyard manure (FYM) along with 25–30 g nitrogen, 20–25 g phosphorus, and 25–30 g potassium per plant annually. For mature plants above 3 years, increase the dose to 30–40 kg FYM, 100–120 g nitrogen, 50–60 g phosphorus, and 100–120 g potassium per plant per year. Nitrogen should be applied in three splits — before sprouting, after sprouting, and during berry growth — while FYM, phosphorus, and potassium should be applied before pruning, which is typically done in January under the Bahar system to induce flowering. Nitrogen can be supplied by 230–250 g urea, phosphorus by 120–130 g DAP, and potassium by 165–180 g muriate of potash (MOP) per plant annually.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing 'Bahar' Context: The most critical flaw. All orchard operations for grapes in Haryana are timed according to the 'bahar' treatment (stress-induced flowering, typically with a single pruning in January). The answer is generic and not tied to this essential local practice.

Impractical Recommendations: It gives nutrient weights (grams of N, P, K) but fails to translate them into quantities of actual fertilizers (e.g., Urea, DAP, MOP), making the advice difficult for a farmer to apply.

Nitrogen can be supplied by 230–250 g urea, phosphorus by 120–130 g DAP, and potassium by 165–180 g muriate of potash (MOP) per plant annually.

MOP conversion: 100 g K₂O ≈ 165 g MOP, 120 g K₂O ≈ 200 g MOP.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Blast In Tomato Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Blast in Tomato crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Blast Disease in Tomato crop?
KccAns: Spray Mancozeb  600 Gm In 200 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control blast in tomato crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Firstly choose Resistant varities like Pusa Ruby, Kashi Aman after that do uprooting of infected plants and burn them, do field sanitation as well as remove weeds and take a foliar spray of Antracol @4gm/lit. or mancozeb @3gm/lit., You can also do drenching with luna or Nativo
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Blast is not a disease in tomato. in tomato we can see Early blight or late blight. early blight look like small circular, dark brown spots on leaves, and in late blight it which cause greasy , water soaked spots. for controlling it you should choose Resistant varities like Pusa Ruby, Kashi Aman after that you can also do uprooting of infected plants and burn them, do field sanitation as well as remove weeds and take a foliar spray of Antracol @4gm/lit. (400gm/acre) or mancozeb @3gm/lit.(450-500gm/acre), take 5-8 days of interval period, You can also do drenching with luna or Nativo(400gm/acre).
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Diagnosis: The answer fails to correct the query. 'Blast' is a rice disease. The correct diseases for tomato are Early Blight (which causes target-like spots) or Late Blight (which causes greasy, water-soaked spots).

Impractical Chemical Advice: The per-litre doses are not standard. A better strategy is a preventive spray of Mancozeb 75% WP at a 500-600 gram/acre rate, and a curative spray of Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole at 200 ml/acre if the disease spreads.

Missing Safety Information: The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI). The waiting period is 7-10 days for Mancozeb and 5 days for the systemic spray, and this must always be included for a vegetable crop.

(400gm/acre) or mancozeb @3gm/lit.(450-500gm/acre), take 5-8 days of interval period, You can also do drenching with luna or Nativo(400gm/acre).

Disease name is either wrong or unclear - "Blast" is not correct terminology for tomato, it could be blight (early or late)

Final Answer:
Blast disease is generally not seen in tomatoes.
In tomato cultivation, the major diseases include Early blight or late blight. early blight looks like small circular, dark brown spots on leaves, and in late blight, it causes greasy, water-soaked spots. For controlling it, first, you should choose resistant varieties like Pusa Ruby and Kashi Aman. After that, you can also do uprooting of infected plants and burn them, do field sanitation as well as remove weeds, and take a foliar spray of Antracol @4gm/lit. (400gm/acre) or mancozeb @3gm/lit.(450-500gm/acre), Take 5-8 days of an interval period. You can also do drenching with Luna or Nativo (400 g/acre).

QueryText: How To Control Of Fruit Borer In Tomato Crop

Primary Answer (Level0): Firstly remove and destroy the infected fruits and plant parts. you can also Use pheromone traps for adult moths and spray insecticides like Spinosad @0.7 ml/lit.or Chlorantraniliprole @0.5/lit. early in the morning. Also you can spraying Neem oil @5-8ml/lit. regularly
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): This fruit borer is a major enemy of tomatoes which cause large loss in tomato crop. firstly, install pheromone traps @10/acre. This will tell you how many borer pests appear, and you can take a spraying dose on the damaging/appearance percentage. if you see any infested fruit, pick it and destroy for spraying, use Spinosad @60-70ml/acre also maintain 8-10 days interval period.

Missing Safety Information: The most critical flaw. The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) or waiting period before harvesting (e.g., 3-5 days depending on the chemical).

Missing Rotation Strategy: It lists two chemicals as an "either/or" choice but fails to explain the essential strategy of rotating them to manage insecticide resistance.

QueryText: How To Control Of Flower Borer In Sunflower
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Flower Borer in Sunflower?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Flower borer in Sunflower?
KccAns: Spray To Endosulfan 35Ec 500Ml In 200 Liter Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of flower borer in sunflower
Primary Answer (Level0): Flower borer in sunflower damages the developing florets and seeds, reducing both yield and quality. If the pest attack is manageable then you can spray Neem oil 10,000 ppm (5ml/l) but if the pest attack is very severe then spray Flubendiamide 20 WG (0.5 g/l) or Spinosad 45 SC (0.3 ml/l).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The flower borer in sunflower causes damage by feeding on the developing florets and seeds, which reduces both the yield and quality of the crop. If not managed on time, it can lead to serious losses. To control the adult moths, you can install around 5 pheromone traps per acre in your field. For natural control, it's good to release Trichogramma chilonis eggs about 50,000 per acre every week, as they help reduce the pest population by targeting the eggs. If the infestation is mild, you can spray neem oil 10,000 ppm at 5 ml per litre of water. But if the attack is severe, then you may use Flubendiamide 20 WG at 40–50 grams per acre or Spinosad 45 SC at 60–70 ml per acre. Just remember, use chemical sprays only when the pest level crosses the economic threshold—usually around 2 larvae per plant to avoid unnecessary spraying and protect the environment too.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Per-Acre Doses: It provides per-litre doses, which are impractical for field crops. The answer must include the per-acre dose (e.g., Flubendiamide at 40-50 grams/acre; Spinosad at 60-70 ml/acre).

Missing Economic Threshold Level (ETL): For a pest like head borer, an expert must advise the farmer to spray only when the pest population reaches the ETL (e.g., 1-2 larvae per plant head), to avoid unnecessary and costly sprays.

QueryText: How To Control Flower Droping In Cucumber
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control flower dropping in Cucumber?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower dropping in Cucumber?
KccAns: Spray Of Etharel  10 Gm In 20 Liter Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control flower droping in cucumber
Primary Answer (Level0): Flower drop in cucumber often happens due to poor pollination, lack of nutrients, or sudden weather changes. To reduce flower dropping, you can spray 10 ml Alpha Naphthyl Acetic Acid 4.5 SL by mixing in 4.5 liters of water during early flowering stage. Alternatively, you can also spray Boron at 2 grams per litre of water during the flowering initiation stage or early fruiting stage. This helps in proper flower development and better fruit setting.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Flower drop in cucumber often happens due to poor pollination, lack of nutrients, or sudden weather changes. To reduce flower dropping, you can spray 1 ml Alpha Naphthyl Acetic Acid 4.5 SL by mixing in 4.5 liters of water during early flowering stage. Alternatively, you can also spray Boron at 2 grams per litre of water during the flowering initiation stage or early fruiting stage. This helps in proper flower development and better fruit setting.
Comment (Reviewer1): Dangerously Incorrect Dosage: It recommends spraying 10 ml of Alpha Naphthyl Acetic Acid (NAA) 4.5 SL in 4.5 liters of water. This is a 10x overdose and is likely to cause severe phytotoxicity (damage) to the sensitive cucumber plant. The correct dose is 1 ml of the chemical in 4.5 litres of water.

QueryText: How To Control Of Flower Droping In Chilli
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Flower dropping in Chilli?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Flower dropping in Chilli?
KccAns: Spray Planofix 1Ml5 Lt Of Water
QueryText_normalized: how to control of flower droping in chilli
Primary Answer (Level0): Flower drop is a common issue in chilli plants and can significantly reduce chilli yield. To control flower drops in chilli, use shade cloth to protect plants from intense sunlight, plant bright coloured flowers nearby chilli field to attract bees and other pollinators, avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizer,  spray NAA(Naphthalene Acetic Acid) @ 10 ppm(1 ml of NAA 4.5 SL per 4-5 litres of water) during early flowering and repeat after 15 days, apply boric acid 0.1% (1 gram per litre of water) at pre flowering and flowering stage, keep soil moist but avoid waterlogged situation, pests like aphids and thrips can cause flower drops, so control them with neem oil @ 3-5 ml per litre of water.

Primary Answer (Level0): Flower drop occurs can be controlled by providing balanced NPK around 110Kg of Urea , 65 kg of DAP and 50 Kg of MOP. Along with ensure irrigation and check for any pest and fugal diseases. Fungal diseases can be controlled by spraying Carbendazim 1 gram for 1 liter of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
Flower drop in Bottle Gourd by either some environmental stress , Nutritional deficiency or Hormonal imbalances. The remedial measures are application of Naphthalene Acetic Acid  4.5 SL prepared by mixing 45-55 ml in 200 liters of water to avoid fruit drop and enhances fruit set. It has to be applied during flowering stage.

Another method is by application of micronutrients such as Borax prepared by mixing 200 gram in 200 liters of water and Calcium nitrate 300 gram in 200 liters of water. Both the nutrients helps in flower retention.

Avoid any long dry spells and waterlogging.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Diagnosis: It wrongly suggests a full NPK fertilizer dose as a direct remedy for flower drop. Flower drop is a physiological issue caused by heat, water, or hormonal stress, not a lack of basal fertilizer.

Wrong Chemical Recommendation: It recommends Carbendazim (a fungicide), which has no effect on physiological flower drop.

Missing Correct Solution: The correct and effective solution involves spraying a plant growth regulator like NAA (Planofix) at 1 ml per 4.5 litres of water and a micronutrient like Boron.

QueryText: How To Control Of Flower Droping In Tomato
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control flower dropping in Tomato?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What practices help reduce flower drop in tomato crops?
KccAns: Spray Of Planofix 1 Ml In 45 Liter Water
QueryText_normalized: how to control of flower droping in tomato
Primary Answer (Level0): Flower dropping in Zaid season tomatoes is mainly caused by the stress of high summer heat and lack of specific nutrients. To manage this, first ensure you provide light and frequent irrigation to keep the soil consistently moist, avoiding both dryness and waterlogging. More importantly, spray a plant growth regulator NAA at a very precise dose of 1 ml mixed in 4.5 litres of water, along with soluble Boron (20%) at a dose of 1 gram per litre of water. This combination spray costs very little but is highly effective, helping the plant to set fruit even in high temperatures and preventing the direct loss of your potential yield.

QueryText: Control Of Foot Rot And Bakani In Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Foot Rot and Bakanae disease in Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I manage Foot rot and Bakanae disease in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray Of Carbendazim  200Gm In 200 Liters Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of foot rot and bakani in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Foot rot and bakanae disease in paddy cause yellowing, wilting, and rotting of seedlings, with some plants showing elongated, weak stems that easily topple. To control these diseases during the Zaid season in Kaithal, treat seeds with Carbendazim 50 WP @ 2 g/kg or Trichoderma viride 5 g/kg seed. Drench nursery beds with 0.25% Carbendazim solution five days before transplanting and uproot seedlings in standing water. Spray Carbendazim 50 WP @ 500 g per acre during flowering to reduce infection. Remove infected debris, ensure good drainage, use resistant varieties, and practice crop rotation to prevent disease spread.

QueryText: Information About Sowing Time Of Chilli
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information about sowing time of Chilli
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of chilli in Haryana?
KccAns: I Told Him Sowing Time Of Chilli :- May-June
QueryText_normalized: information about sowing time of chilli
Primary Answer (Level0): For a Zaid (summer) chilli crop, sow the nursery between late October and mid-November, and then transplant the seedlings into your main field in the first half of February. This timing is crucial as your harvest will then hit the market in the hot summer months of May and June. During this period, prices are often 25-50% higher than the main season crop, which ensures you get an excellent profit.

Primary Answer (Level0): For better okra yield, farmers should go for improved varieties developed at CCS HAU (Chaudhary Charan Singh Haryana Agricultural University), Hisar, like Hisar Unnat (HRB‑55), Varsha Uphar, and Hisar Naveen. These are resistant to Yellow Vein Mosaic Virus (YVMV), mature early (first picking around 46–47 days), and yield approximately 40.5–52.6 quintals per acre. They perform well in both spring‑summer and monsoon seasons, giving good fruit size (15–20 cm) and quality. Always use certified seeds and treat the seeds with Trichoderma viride at @ 4 grams per kg or Captan 50% WP at 2-2.5 grams per kg of seed to protect seedlings. You can buy from your local HAU‑certified dealers or trusted agro‑stores or FPO; otherwise, you can consult with KVK for a healthy, high‑yielding crop.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Aphids In Mustard Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Aphids in Mustard Crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Aphids in Mustard?
KccAns: Spray 100 Ml Confidor In 150 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control aphids in mustard crop
Primary Answer (Level0): For biological control of aphids in mustard spray neem oil 10,000 ppm (400-600 ml/acre). If the pest attack is very severe and cannot be controlled by biological control then spray Chlorpyrifos 20 EC (200 ml/acre) or Oxydemeton-methyl 25 % EC (400 ml/acre) or Thiamethoxam 25 % WG (20-40 g/acre). Do not use the same chemical every year always rotate them so to avoid resistance in pests.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): For biological control of aphids in mustard spray neem oil 10,000 ppm (400-600 ml/acre). If the pest attack is very severe and cannot be controlled by biological control then spray Chlorpyrifos 20 EC (200 ml/acre) or Oxydemeton-methyl 25 % EC (400 ml/acre) or Thiamethoxam 25 % WG (20-40 g/acre). Do not use the same chemical every year always rotate them so to avoid resistance in pests. Spray should be done only when aphids cross the Economic Threshold Level (ETL), which is 20–25 aphids per 10 cm of the central shoot. This avoids unnecessary spraying, saves input cost, and protects beneficial insects.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Economic Threshold Level (ETL): The most important and money-saving advice for mustard aphid is to spray only when the pest reaches the ETL. The answer should state that spraying is recommended only when an average of 20-25 aphids are seen per 10 cm of the central shoot. This prevents unnecessary sprays and saves the farmer money.

Do not use the same chemical every year always rotate them so to avoid resistance in pests. Spray should be done only when aphids cross the Economic Threshold Level (ETL), which is 20–25 aphids per 10 cm of the central shoot. This avoids unnecessary spraying, saves input cost, and protects beneficial insects.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Neem at 5 ml/l—equates to about 1 L/acre in 200 L water, not 400–600 ml; clarify dosage.

Chlorpyrifos 20 EC is often used at 1 L/acre, not 200 ml.
Oxydemeton-methyl 25 EC at 500 ml/acre is common.

Add note on pre-harvest intervals to ensure safe produce.

QueryText: How To Control Black Kidi In Sugarcane Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Black Kidi (Black bug) in Sugarcane?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I manage the problem of black kidi (black bug) in sugarcane?
KccAns: Spray To Endosulfan 550 Ml In 500 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control black kidi in sugarcane crop
Primary Answer (Level0): For controlling black bug in sugarcane, Spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100 ml/acre or Fipronil 5 SC @ 400 ml/acre in 200 litres of water during early morning or evening when bugs are active by cultural methods include deep summer ploughing kills larva, practicing crop rotation, avoiding trash mulching, and maintaining proper field sanitation to reduce pest hiding spots and prevent infestation.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): For controlling black bug in sugarcane, spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100 ml/acre or Fipronil 5 SC @ 400 ml/acre in 200 liters of water during early morning or evening when the bugs are most active. Cultural control methods include deep summer ploughing to kill larvae, practicing crop rotation, maintaining proper field sanitation to reduce pest hiding spots, and continuing trash mulching, which is recommended for conserving moisture and improving soil health in Haryana. It is important to note that black bug is primarily a pest of ratoon crops after the main harvest, so control efforts should be focused during this stage for better results.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Cultural Advice: The most significant error is recommending "avoiding trash mulching." Sugarcane trash mulching is a highly recommended practice in Haryana for conserving moisture and improving soil health. An expert would never advise against it for black bug control.

Missing Strategic Context: It fails to mention when this pest is a major problem. An expert answer must clarify that the Black Bug is primarily a pest of the ratoon crop after the main harvest, and control efforts should be focused there.

It is important to note that black bug is primarily a pest of ratoon crops after the main harvest, so control efforts should be focused during this stage for better results.

Fipronil 5% SC dose correct, but spray volume should be 150–200 L/acre.

Trash mulching may favour some pest harbouring if not managed—should be clarified.

QueryText: How To Control Of Fruit Fly In Cucumber
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Fruit Fly in Cucumber?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Fruit fly in Cucumber?
KccAns: Spray To Mailathion  300 Ml In 200 Litre Of Water Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of fruit fly in cucumber
Primary Answer (Level0): For controlling fruit fly in cucumber in Haryana region, use resistant varieties like Pusa Uday or Punjab Naveen and also destroy the infected plant parts after that you can Set up pheromone traps (10-12/acre) and spray Neem oil 5% or Malathion 2ml/lit.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers in the Haryana region, you can use resistant varieties like Pusa Uday or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Correct Lure Name: This is a major technical error. It mentions pheromone traps but fails to specify that the correct lure for cucumber fruit fly is Cuelure.

Missing Safety Information: The advice is unsafe as it completely omits the mandatory Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI). For Malathion, this is 5-7 days.

Impractical Dosage: It provides a per-litre dosage instead of the more effective and standard per-acre bait spray recommendation (e.g., 200 ml Malathion + 200g Jaggery).
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers in the Haryana region, you can use resistant varieties like Pusa Uday or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Resistant varieties against fruit fly are limited; Pusa Uday is not specifically fruit fly resistant.

Missing sanitation and field hygiene measures.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers , you can use slightly resistant varieties like Saira 934, saloni or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery. Always do field sanitation and maintain field hygiene .
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers , you can use slightly resistant varieties like Saira 934, saloni or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery. Always do field sanitation and maintain field hygiene .
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers , you can use slightly resistant varieties like Saira 934, saloni or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery. Always do field sanitation and maintain field hygiene .
Final Answer: For controlling fruit flies in cucumbers, you can use slightly resistant varieties like Saira 934, Saloni, or Punjab Naveen, which are resistant to fruit flies, sticky insects, etc., and also destroy the infected plant parts. After that, you can set up pheromone traps (cuelure) (10-12/acre) and spray 5% neem oil (100 ml/acre) or 200 ml/acre Malathion + 200 g jaggery. Always do field sanitation and maintain field hygiene.

QueryText: Control Of Fruit Droping In Lemon
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control fruit dropping in Lemon?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control Fruit dropping in Lemon plants?
KccAns: Spray Of Bavistin  500 Gm In 500 Liters Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: control of fruit droping in lemon
Primary Answer (Level0): For controlling the fruit dropping in lemon in Haryana side, you have to give proper irrigation, avoiding water stress, and apply balanced fertilizers, like nitrogen, potassium, and zinc. also there are some micronutrients/water soluble fertilizer are available like Califert etc. and also you can use growth regulators like NAA.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Fruit dropping in lemon trees during the hot Zaid season is mainly caused by water stress and a lack of key nutrients. First, ensure that you maintain consistent moisture in the soil by giving regular irrigation in the tree basin. Spray a plant growth regulator like Planofix (NAA) at a very precise dose of 1 ml mixed in 4.5 liters of water. For better fruit health and retention, it is also highly beneficial to spray a mix of zinc sulfate (3 gm/liter of water). These combined methods significantly reduce fruit dropping as well as increase your final harvest and income.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Lacks All Essential Numbers: It provides no specific application doses. The recommendation for the hormone NAA is useless and dangerous without a precise dose, which is 1 ml in 4.5 litres of water.

Vague Recommendations: It mentions "balanced fertilizers" and a generic product name ("Califert") instead of providing specific, standard recommendations like a spray of Zinc Sulphate at 3 grams per litre of water.

NAA dose (1 ml/4.5 L) correct but must mention max two sprays at pea-size and marble-size stage.

Zinc sulphate dose incomplete; should mention adding lime to avoid leaf burn.

Corrections:
“Spray zinc sulphate @ 3 g/l + lime @ 1.5 g/l with NAA at fruit set stage. Repeat after 15 days if drop persists.”

QueryText: How To Control Of White Lut In Bajra
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control White Lut (White grub) in Bajra?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What practices should be followed to manage white lut (white grub) in bajra?
KccAns: Spray Of Monocrotophas 250 Ml In 250 Liter Water Per Acer
QueryText_normalized: how to control of white lut in bajra
Primary Answer (Level0): For controlling white grubs in bajra Give soil treatment before or at the time of sowing by applying Carbofuran 3G granules @10 kg/acre and to control the adult beetles foliar spray can be applied spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL@ 100 ml/acre additionally Cultural methods include Deep Summer Ploughing to kill pupae,Practice Crop Rotation and maintain field sanitation.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): To control white grubs in bajra, apply soil treatment before or at the time of sowing by using Fipronil 0.3% granules @ 10–12 kg per acre. For controlling adult beetles, foliar spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100 ml per acre can be applied as needed.In addition to chemical control, adopt cultural practices such as deep summer ploughing to destroy pupae in the soil, crop rotation to break the pest cycle, and maintain proper field sanitation by removing crop residues and weeds.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Recommends a BANNED Chemical: The biggest flaw. It recommends Carbofuran, which is a highly toxic and banned pesticide in India for most uses. An expert must never recommend it.

Missing Safe Alternatives: A safe and legal recommendation for soil application would be to use Fipronil 0.3% GR at 10-12 kg per acre at the time of sowing.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): To control white grubs in bajra, apply soil treatment before or at the time of sowing by using Fipronil 0.3% granules @ 10–12 kg per acre.
