QueryText_normalized: informaton regarding sowing time of cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Mainly in Haryana region, cotton is sown from April to mid-june, where   rainfall is started upto this soil temperature reaches 20â€“25Â°C.for an sowing the Recommended varieties are like CSH 3129, CSH 3075, and RS-2013, which are high-yielding and resistant to pests and cotton leaf curl virus.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Haryana cotton is mainly sown from mid-April to May, when the temp. ranges up to 20-25°C. Sowing during this period allows the plant to develop a deep root system before the monsoon, making it stronger. More importantly, it helps to crop from the peak attack of whitefly, which can save you the cost of one or two early sprays. you can take RCH 659 BG-II and MRC 7017 BG-II it gives yield upto (10-12q/hec.) also you can use CSH 3129 and CSH 3075 which give yield (9-11q/hec).
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Season: It fails to correct the user's premise. Cotton is a Kharif crop in Haryana, not a Zaid crop.

Incorrect Sowing Information: It incorrectly links sowing time to the start of "rainfall." In Haryana, cotton is sown in April-May using pre-sowing irrigation (palewa), well before the monsoon.

Incomplete Variety Advice: It only lists Desi cotton varieties and completely omits the more common and high-yielding commercial Bt hybrids. It also provides no yield numbers.

QueryText: The Deficiency Of Iron And Nitrogen In Nursery Of Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to prevent Iron and Nitrogen deficiency in Paddy nursery?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to prevent Iron and Nitrogen deficiency in Paddy nursery?
KccAns: Apply To Urea  3 Kg Kanal And Spray To Ferrous Sulphate  5  Solution After 15 Days At Sowing Time
QueryText_normalized: the deficiency of iron and nitrogen in nursery of paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Nitrogen deficiency is often seen in paddy nursery due to inadequate nitrogen fertilization or loss from leaching in poorly managed nurseries, and due to this lower/older leaves become yellow, seedlings become weak, and produce less tiller. While Iron deficiency is common in poorly drained and in alkaline soil(high soil pH), due to this young leaves become yellow while veins remain remain green. To correct nitrogen deficiency in paddy nursery apply 26 kg urea per acre during bed preparation and split it into two dose first at 7-10 days after sowing and second at 15-18 days after sowing, or you can use 2% urea spray(mix 20 gram urea per litre of water) and spray in morning or evening. To correct iron deficiency prevent waterlogging, add well decomposed organic manure during bed preparation,  spray Ferrous sulphate@ 0.5% (5 gram ferrous sulphate per litre of water) 2-3 times at 5-7 days interval and if possible apply sulphur based on your soil type to raise soil pH.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Nitrogen deficiency is often seen in paddy nurseries due to inadequate nitrogen fertilization or loss from leaching in poorly managed nurseries, and due to this, lower/older leaves become yellow, seedlings become weak, and they produce fewer tillers. While iron deficiency is common in poorly drained and in alkaline soil (high soil pH), due to this, young leaves become yellow while veins remain green. To correct nitrogen deficiency in paddy nursery, apply 26 kg urea per acre during bed preparation and split it into two doses: the first at 7-10 days after sowing and the second at 15-18 days after sowing, or you can use 2% urea spray (mix 20 grams urea per liter of water) and spray in the morning or evening. To correct iron deficiency and prevent waterlogging, add well-decomposed organic manure during bed preparation, spray ferrous sulfate at 0.5% (5 grams of ferrous sulfate per liter of water) 2-3 times at 5-7 day intervals, and if possible, apply sulfur based on your soil type to lower soil pH.
Comment (Reviewer1): Incorrect Scientific Advice: In the section for Iron deficiency, it states that applying sulphur will "raise soil pH". This is completely wrong. Sulphur is an acidifying agent and is applied to LOWER the soil pH, which in turn helps make iron more available to the plant. This is a critical factual error.

To correct iron deficiency and prevent waterlogging, add well-decomposed organic manure during bed preparation, spray ferrous sulfate at 0.5% (5 grams of ferrous sulfate per liter of water) 2-3 times at 5-7 day intervals, and if possible, apply sulfur based on your soil type to lower soil pH.
Comment (Reviewer2): Iron spray should be combined with lime to prevent leaf burn; this is missing.

QueryText: Control Of Disease In Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control diseases in Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Diseases in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray 2 Gm M-45 Or Bavastin Or Copper Oxy Chloride  Liter Water
QueryText_normalized: control of disease in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): One of the diseases in rice is Blast and it appears as brown spots on leaves ; it can be managed by spraying Tricyclazole 75 WP 0.6 g per litre of water. Another disease is Sheath Blight shows up as grey-green oval   at the base of the plant and is best controlled by Propiconazole 25 EC  1 ml per litre. Bacterial Leaf Blight (BLB) causes yellowing from leaf tips downward, and can be managed by spraying Streptocycline 0.01% along with  Copper Oxychloride @ 2.5 g per litre of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
One of the diseases in rice is Blast and it appears as brown spots on leaves ; it can be managed by spraying 120gram Tricyclazole 75 WP mixed in 200 liters of water and sprayed. The first ap[plication is when the initial appearance of the disease.

Another disease is Sheath Blight shows up as grey-green oval at the base of the plant and is best controlled by Propiconazole 25 EC prepared by mixing 200 ml of it in 200 liters of water.

Bacterial Leaf Blight (BLB) causes yellowing from leaf tips downward, and can be managed by split application of nitrogen as the first control measure as nitrogen causes more growth of leaves and can spread the disease. Top dressing with nitrogen spraying Streptocycline  along with Copper Oxychloride. Streptocycline 150mg mixed with Copper oxychloride 200 gram in 200 liters of water and sprayed. There should be a waiting period of 21 days
Comment (Reviewer1):
Impractical Dosages: All recommendations are given in "g/litre" or "ml/litre." For field crops, an expert must provide the per-acre dose for each chemical (e.g., Tricyclazole at 120 grams/acre; Propiconazole at 200 ml/acre).

Missing Safety Information: It recommends an antibiotic (Streptocycline) without mentioning the Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI), which is a critical safety instruction.

Incomplete Strategy: For Bacterial Leaf Blight (BLB), a key management tip is to stop top-dressing with nitrogen fertilizer, which is missing.

Top dressing with nitrogen spraying Streptocycline  along with Copper Oxychloride. Streptocycline 150mg mixed with Copper oxychloride 200 gram in 200 liters of water and sprayed. There should be a waiting period of 21 days

Tricyclazole 75 WP dose correct (120 g/acre) but apply twice at 10-day interval for blast.

Streptocycline dose too high: 150 mg in 200 L water/acre, not with 200 g copper oxychloride unless label allows.

QueryText: The Sowing Time Of Paddy Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: What is the sowing time of Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended sowing time of the Paddy crop?
KccAns: The Sowing Time Of Paddy Crop Is 15 May  30 Jun
QueryText_normalized: the sowing time of paddy crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Paddy Is a major crop in harayana region where it was timely sowing June-July for better plant health and it also reduce infestation of disease, so you can choose PR 126 this is resistant to bacterial leaf blight and also give better yield or HKR 47 which are tolerant to blast disease. For late sowing up to mid-July, you can go for PAU 201 which is suitable for delayed conditions. These varieties yield well (30-35 quintals/acre) with proper water management.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Paddy It is a major crop in the Haryana region, where it was sown in a nursery from mid-May and transplanted in June-July for better plant health, and it also reduces infestation of disease, so you can choose PR 126, which is resistant to bacterial leaf blight and also gives a better yield, or HKR 47, which is tolerant to blast disease. For late sowing in the nursery stage at mid-July, you can go for PAU 201, which is suitable for delayed conditions. These varieties yield well (28-32 quintals/acre) with proper water management.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Unclear Sowing Process: The biggest flaw. It says "sowing June-July." This is ambiguous. An expert must clarify the critical two-stage process for a transplanted crop: Nursery Sowing is done from mid-May to mid-June, and the Transplanting of those seedlings into the main field is done from mid-June to mid-July.

Slightly Optimistic Yield: The yield of "30-35 quintals/acre" is at the very high end. A more realistic range for these varieties under typical farm conditions is 28-32 quintals per acre.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Paddy It is a major crop in the Haryana region, where it was sown in a nursery from mid-May and transplanted in June-July for better plant health, and it also reduces infestation of disease, so you can choose PR 126, which is resistant to bacterial leaf blight and also gives a better yield, or HKR 47, which is tolerant to blast disease. For late sowing in the nursery stage at mid-July, you can go for PAU 201, which is suitable for delayed conditions. These varieties yield well (28-32 quintals/acre) with proper water management.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Yields per acre seem inflated — Haryana averages 25–30 q/acre under good conditions.

Maybe refer to PR 126, PR 127 or HKR series for delayed rice.

Include standard seed rate (~18 kg nursery/acre) and spacing (20 × 10 cm).

QueryText: The Control Of Pera Wilt In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Para Wilt in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How can I control parawilt in the Cotton crop?
KccAns: Spray To Cobalt Chloride  1 Gm In 100 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: the control of pera wilt in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Para wilt is a physiological disorder it is also called a sudden wilting in cotton crop due to sudden weather and irrigation  changes especially in heavy clay or poorly drained soils it causes rapid wilting of leaves, plants may dry up or collapse. To manage para wilting in cotton choose wilt tolerant mid to late maturing varieties, avoid sudden heavy irrigation after dry spells use frequent light irrigations to prevent water logging, Always use balance nutrients avoid excessive nitrogen during mid season. Or you can give foliar spray of Cobalt chloride @ 10mg/litre of water as soon as symptoms appearance.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Para wilt is a physiological disorder it is also called sudden wilting, in cotton crops due to sudden weather and irrigation changes, especially in heavy clay or poorly drained soils. It causes rapid wilting of leaves; plants may dry up or collapse. To manage para wilting in cotton, choose wilt-tolerant mid to late maturing varieties like CHS-3129, CHS 3075, LD-694, and LD-327. Avoid sudden heavy irrigation after dry spells. Use frequent light irrigations to prevent waterlogging. Always use balanced nutrients to avoid excessive nitrogen during mid-season. Or you can give a foliar spray of Cobalt chloride @ 10mg/litre of water as soon as the symptoms appear.

QueryText: How To Control Of Mandusi In Wheat
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Mandusi (Phalaris minor) in Wheat?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Phalaris minor (mandusi) in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray Of Isoprutan 700 Gm In 200 Liter Water Per Acre After Sowing 30 Days
QueryText_normalized: how to control of mandusi in wheat
Primary Answer (Level0): Phalaris minor (mandusi) in wheat is a stubborn weed that competes fiercely for nutrients, water, and sunlight, slashing your yield if not controlled in time. To control phalaris minor in wheat spray Flumioxazin 50 SC (100 ml/acre) or Metribuzin 70 WP (250 g/acre) or Clodinafop- propargyl 15 WP (320 g/acre). Mix any one of the herbicide in 200 liters of water and spray on the weed after 30-35 days of sowing wheat.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Phalaris minor (Mandusi) is a stubborn weed in wheat fields that fights for water, sunlight, and nutrients reducing your yield significantly if not managed early. While herbicides like Flumioxazin 50 SC (100 ml/acre), Metribuzin 70 WP (250 g/acre), or Clodinafop-propargyl 15 WP (320 g/acre) are commonly used, in Haryana many fields now face herbicide resistance, especially to older solutions like Clodinafop. To tackle this, it is now recommend using a modern ready-mix herbicide like Sulfosulfuron + Metsulfuron-methyl (13.5 g/acre), which is effective even in resistant weed populations. Mix the selected herbicide in 200 liters of water per acre and spray uniformly at 30–35 days after sowing, when weeds are actively growing. Always follow safety and label instructions, rotate herbicides yearly to avoid resistance, and adopt proper weed scouting for long-term success.

QueryText_normalized: madusi weeds control in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Phalaris minor, is a major weed in wheat cultivation and it is commonly known as Madusi . You can manage it through both cultural and chemical methods. Culturally, follow early sowing, practice crop rotation, and use the ideal seed rate. Chemically, apply Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) @ 1.3 liters/acre as a pre-emergence herbicide, before or within 2 days of sowing. For post-emergence control, use Axial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) @ 400 ml/acre or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron + Iodosulfuron) @ 160 g/acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Phalaris minor, commonly known as Madusi in Haryana and Punjab and it is a major weed in wheat cultivation, under irrigated conditions. It can be managed by both cultural and chemical methods. Culturally, practice early sowing, maintain the recommended seed rate, and adopt crop rotation. Chemically, apply a pre-emergence herbicides like Stomp (Pendimethalin 30% EC) at 1.3 litres per acre, either before or within 2 days of sowing. For post-emergence control, options include Axial (Pinoxaden 5% EC) at 400 ml/acre or Atlantis (Mesosulfuron + Iodosulfuron) at 160 g/acre.Rotate herbicides with different modes of action each year, and avoid relying on the same chemical repeatedly.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Root Rot In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Root rot in Cotton crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Root Rot In Cotton Crop?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Root Rot In Cotton Crop Informatio Regarding How To Control Fungal Disease In Cotton Crop Spray Bavistin  400 Gm In 200 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control root rot in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Root rot symptoms in cotton are sudden wilting of healthy plants and dark brown to black rot at root base or stem collar. To control root rot in cotton during the Zaid season in Adampur, Hisar, apply Carbendazim 400 g or Copper oxychloride 1 kg per acre as a soil drench in 200 liters of water near the plant base. Treat seeds with Carbendazim (2 g/kg) before sowing, avoid waterlogging, and remove infected plants. Maintain proper spacing to improve air flow. Remove and burn wilted plants early. Practice crop rotation with non-host crops like bajra, maize.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Cotton is strictly a Kharif crop in Haryana, sown between April and June and harvested from October onwards. Root rot symptoms in cotton are sudden wilting of healthy plants and dark brown to black rot at root base or stem collar.  Maintain proper spacing to improve air flow. Remove and burn wilted plants early. Practice crop rotation with non-host crops like bajra, maize. For seed treatment, use Thiram @ 3 g/kg seed. For soil drenching, Copper Oxychloride @ 1 kg/acre in 200 liters of water remains effective, and biological control using Trichoderma viride @ 2.5 kg/acre mixed with compost or FYM is a sustainable.

QueryText: How To Control Rust In  Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Rust in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Rust in Wheat Crop?
KccAns: Spray Of Daithain M-45  600 Gm In 200 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: how to control rust in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Rust is a fungal disease that spreads fast in cool and moist weather, reducing wheat yield and grain quality. Early control is important because once rust spreads, it damages the crop yield badly. At first sign of yellow or brown rust, spray Propiconazole 25% EC @ 200 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Repeat after 15 days if needed. You can also use Tebuconazole 25.9% EC @ 200 ml per acre or Azoxystrobin 11% along with Tebuconazole 18.3% SC @ 300 ml per acre. Use fan type nozzle for evenly spraying and spray in the morning or evening. Grow rust-tolerant varieties like WH 1105, or DBW 187 for better resistance. Early spray gives best control and saves your crop.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Rust is a fungal disease that spreads fast in cool and moist weather, reducing wheat yield and grain quality. Early control is important because once rust spreads, it damages the crop yield badly. At first sign of yellow or brown rust, spray Propiconazole 25% EC @ 200 ml per acre in 200 litres of water. Repeat after 15 days if needed. You can also use as an alternative purpose Tebuconazole 25.9% EC @ 200 ml per acre or Azoxystrobin 11% along with Tebuconazole 18.3% SC @ 300 ml per acre. Use flat fan nozzle for evenly spraying and spray in the morning or evening. Don't use same chemical every time keep rotation to reduce pest attract. Grow rust-tolerant varieties like WH 1105, or DBW 187 for better resistance. Early spray gives best control and saves your crop.

QueryText: Information Regarding Seed Rate Of Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the seed rate of Paddy
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the recommended seed rate of Paddy?
KccAns: I Told The Kisan Seed Rate Of Paddy:- 8 Kgacre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding seed rate of paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Seed rate depends on method of sowing. For transplanting the recommended seed rate for Bhiwani district is 20-30 kg per acre, for direct seeded method(DSR) the recommended seed rate is 35-50 kg per acre, and for SRI method the recommended seed rate is 5-8 kg per acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): In Bhiwani district, Haryana, the recommended paddy seed rate depends on the sowing method and variety—for transplanting, use 8–10 kg per acre for non-Basmati (e.g., PR series), 8 kg per acre for Pusa Basmati 1121, and only 5–6 kg per acre for high-tillering varieties like Pusa Basmati 1509; for the Direct Seeded Rice (DSR) method using a seed drill, the seed rate for all varieties should be 8–10 kg per acre, as these lower rates prevent overcrowding, reduce disease risk, and support better tillering and yield.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Critically Incorrect & Wasteful Rates: The rates provided (20-30 kg/acre for transplanting, 35-50 kg/acre for DSR) are extremely high. Following this advice would cause a massive financial loss in wasted seed and lead to a poor, disease-prone, and lodged (fallen over) crop.

The Science of Modern Varieties: The reason for the error is that modern paddy varieties—both Basmati and non-Basmati—have a very high tillering capacity (one healthy seedling produces many stems). Using the old high seed rates causes severe overcrowding, which suppresses tillering and increases the risk of disease.

Correct, Sourced Recommendations for Haryana: The official advice from research institutes is much lower and depends on the specific paddy type:

For Non-Basmati (Parmal) varieties like the PR series: The correct transplanting seed rate is 8-10 kg per acre.

For Basmati varieties like Pusa Basmati 1121: The rate is 8 kg per acre.

For high-tillering Basmati like Pusa Basmati 1509: The rate is only 5-6 kg per acre.

For the Direct Seeding (DSR) method with a drill, the optimal rate for all varieties is 8-10 kg per acre.

Using these lower, scientifically-backed rates for the specific paddy type is the expert method to save farmers money and achieve a healthier, higher-yielding crop.

QueryText: Information Regarding Seed Treatment Of Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the seed treatment of Cotton
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to do seed treatment in Cotton?
KccAns: The Treat The Seed Cotton  Amisan 5Gm Steptosycilen 1Gm Secsinic 1Gm Water Cotton Seed 56 Kg Hairey And 68 Kg No Hairey
QueryText_normalized: information regarding seed treatment of cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Seed treatment in cotton is a crucial practice for protecting seeds and seedlings from various soil borne and seed borne diseases. To remove fuzz (lint) from the seed surface use commercial concentrated sulfuric acid @ 200 gram per kg of cotton seed and mix seeds and acid in glass container and stir for 2-3 minutes, wash thoroughly 3-4 times with water followed by dry in shade for 1-2 days before treatment. Treat delinited or dried seed with fungicides like Thiram or Bavistin (carbendazim 50 WP) @ 2 gram per kg to protect against seed borne diseases, and if you want to use biofertilizer, you can use Azospirillum + PSB @ 200 gram per kg seed. To protect cotton seed against early sucking pests like jassids, aphids you can additionally use Imidacloprid 70 WS @ 3 gram per kg of seed.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Cotton is mainly grown as kharif crop in Haryana and zaid season is not suitable for cotton cultivation in this region. If the farmers use Bt hybrid cotton seeds,  which are pre-treated by seed companies with a polymer coating that contains approved fungicides and insecticides, then additional seed treatment is not required, re-treating pre-treated seeds can harm their viability or result in phytotoxicity. If farmer used untreated seeds then only treat seed with fungicides and insecticides. To remove fuzz (lint) from the seed surface use commercial concentrated sulfuric acid @ 200 gram per kg of cotton seed and mix seeds and acid in glass container and stir for 2-3 minutes, wash thoroughly 3-4 times with water followed by dry in shade for 1-2 days before treatment. Treat delinited or dried seed with fungicides like Thiram @ 2 gram per kg to protect against seed borne diseases, and if you want to use biofertilizer, you can use Azospirillum + PSB @ 200 gram per kg seed. To protect cotton seed against early sucking pests like jassids, aphids you can additionally use Imidacloprid 70 WS @ 3 gram per kg of seed.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Recommends an Obsolete Practice: The biggest flaw is that it describes acid delinting and manual seed treatment. An expert must clarify that in Haryana, virtually all commercial farmers use Bt hybrid seeds, which already come pre-treated by the seed company with a polymer coating containing the necessary fungicides and insecticides. Advising a farmer to perform these steps on a pre-treated Bt seed packet is incorrect and unnecessary.

Incorrect Season: The answer fails to correct the query's premise. An expert answer must state clearly that Cotton is a Kharif crop in Haryana, sown in April-May, not a Zaid crop.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Shoot Borer In Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Shoot borer in Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Shoot borer in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray 500 Ml Monocrotophos  200 Gm Carbendazim In 200 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control shoot borer in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Shoot borer in paddy causes 'dead heart' symptoms by boring into the central shoot, leading to severe yield loss if not controlled early. For controlling shoot borer in paddy spray Bifenthrin 8.8 CS (200 ml/acre) or Bifenthrin 10 % EC (200 ml/acre) or Cartap Hydrochloride 50 SP (400 g/acre) or Chlorantraniliprole 00.40 GR (broadcast 4 kg in per acre followed by light irrigation).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Shoot borer in paddy causes 'dead heart' symptoms by boring into the central shoot, leading to severe yield loss if not controlled early. For controlling shoot borer in paddy spray Bifenthrin 8.8 CS (200 ml/acre) or Bifenthrin 10 % EC (200 ml/acre) or Cartap Hydrochloride 50 SP (400 g/acre) or Chlorantraniliprole 00.40 GR (broadcast 4 kg in per acre followed by light irrigation). Apply control measures 20-30 days after transplanting to target the pest at its most vulnerable early stage.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Strategic Guidance: It lists sprays and granules as equal options. An expert must clarify when to use each. For the early "dead heart" stage, the whorl application of granules (like Cartap Hydrochloride 4G or Chlorantraniliprole 0.4 GR) is far more effective and easier than a spray because the pest is deep inside the plant's central shoot.

Missing Application Timing: The advice should specify that these control measures are most effective when applied 20-30 days after transplanting to target the pest at its most vulnerable early stage.

QueryText: Information Regarding To The Sowing Time Of Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the sowing time of Cotton
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the sowing time of Cotton?
KccAns: To The Sowing Time Of Cotton Is 15 April - 7 June
QueryText_normalized: information regarding to the sowing time of cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): Sowing cotton on time is a non-negotiable rule for good yield. The perfect window is from mid April to May. Sowing during this period allows the plant to develop a deep root system before the monsoon, making it stronger. More importantly, it helps the crop escape the peak attack period of whitefly, which can save you the cost and effort of at least one to two early sprays.

QueryText: Deficincy Of Zinc Sulphate In Paddy Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Deficiency of Zinc sulphate in Paddy crop
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to protect from Zinc sulphate deficiency in the Paddy crop?
KccAns: Spray Zinc Sulphate  500 Gm 1 Kg Urea In 100 Litre Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: deficincy of zinc sulphate in paddy crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Spray at basal application - (Zinc Sulphate Heptahydrate-25kg/acre), foliar spray (Zinc Sulphate-5 kg/acre dissolved in 200 liters of water) and Lime (2.5 kg/acre to neutralize acidity) Best done in morning or late evening to avoid leaf burn.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Paddy is a Mostly grown in kharif season crop in all over India, but Paddy also cultivated in Zaid season. But Zinc deficiency causes lack of Zn sulphate, excess phosphate fertilizers and continuous flooding or over irrigation in field and symptoms are Yellowing of young leaves, especially at the base, White or pale brown streaks along midribs, Bronzing of leaf tips, necrosis, Stunted plant growth, poor root system, Delayed maturity, reduced panicle size and grain yield. To control Zn sulphate deficiency in paddy, use Soil (basal) application - Zinc Sulphate (21% Zn) 10 kg/acre and Foliar spray - Zinc Sulphate 0.5%/acre in 200 litres of water.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Paddy is the main Kharif crop in Haryana.

The recommended rates for both basal and foliar application are dangerously high.

Basal Application: The standard recommendation is 25 kg of Zinc Sulphate per hectare, which is equivalent to 10 kg per acre. The suggested 25 kg/acre is 2.5 times the correct dose and is excessive.   

Foliar Spray: The standard recommendation is a 0.5% solution of Zinc Sulphate. In 200 litres of water, this requires 1 kg of Zinc Sulphate, not 5 kg. A 5 kg dose would create a 2.5% solution that will cause severe chemical burn on the leaves

- The phrase "Spray at basal application" is contradictory.

Basal application is done to the soil, not as a spray. The phrasing should be corrected to "For soil (basal) application..." and "For foliar spray..." to distinguish the two different methods clearly.

QueryText: Control Of Root Weevil In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Root Weevil in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control root weevil in wheat crop?
KccAns: Spray Of Endosulfan  500 Ml In 200 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of root weevil in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0):
Symptoms include yellowing plants, wilting, root damages to control by chemically Apply
or drench soil with Reagent (Fipronil) 500ml/ac and for Foliar Spray karate(Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC)120 ml/ac  Tall star (Bifenthrin 10% EC ) Use 400ml/ac to target adults. you can control it by usinh cultural practices like crop rotation with legumes to increase soil fertility and Nitrogen fixation, remove weeds and crop residues, and select resistant wheat varieties.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Root weevils are soil-dwelling beetles whose larvae feed on plant roots, leading to symptoms such as yellowing, wilting, stunted growth, and in severe cases, plant death root systems. For chemical control, drenching the soil with Fipronil 5% SC @ 500 ml/acre or Foliar sprays like Bifenthrin 10% EC @ 400 ml/acre .Culturally, practice crop rotation, and maintain field sanitation by removing crop residues and weeds that may harbour adults. Deep summer ploughing can help. While root weevils are not typically a major threat in cereals like wheat, regular field scouting is important to detect early infestations and avoid misdiagnosis with similar soil pests like termites or root grubs.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Incorrect Pest Diagnosis: The biggest flaw. "Root Weevil" is not a major pest of wheat in Haryana. The symptoms described (yellowing, wilting, root damage) are the classic signs of Termites. An expert must correct this diagnosis.

Missing Primary Control Method: Because the pest is termites, the most important, effective, and economical control method is seed treatment with a chemical like Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam before sowing. The answer completely omits this primary recommendation.

Deep summer ploughing can help. While root weevils are not typically a major threat in cereals like wheat, regular field scouting is important to detect early infestations and avoid misdiagnosis with similar soil pests like termites or root grubs.

Bifenthrin foliar spray is ineffective against soil larvae.
- Focus on seed treatment (Imidacloprid 600 FS @ 10 ml/kg) + cultural controls (deep ploughing, residue removal).
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Root weevils are soil-dwelling beetles whose larvae feed on plant roots, leading to symptoms such as yellowing, wilting, stunted growth, and in severe cases, plant death root systems. Deep summer ploughing can help. While root weevils are not typically a major threat in cereals like wheat, regular field scouting is important to detect early infestations and avoid misdiagnosis with similar soil pests like termites or root grubs.
Comment (Reviewer3): The text suggests using a foliar spray of Bifenthrin 10% EC at 400 ml/acre for controlling root weevils. While Bifenthrin is a potent insecticide, a foliar spray is generally ineffective for a soil-dwelling pest like the root weevil larva. The primary target for controlling root weevils is the larvae in the soil. A foliar application will only affect the adult weevils, which are not the primary cause of the most severe root damage. Follow Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam based seed treatment. These systemic insecticides provide protection against soil-sucking and root-feeding insect pests including root weevil larvae in the early growth stages.

While they are not usually a major threat to wheat, regular scouting is important to detect infestations early and distinguish them from similar pests like termites or root grubs. Chemical control includes soil drenching with Fipronil 5% SC at 500 ml per acre, which targets larvae in the soil. Seed treatment with systemic insecticides such as Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam is recommended for early protection against root-feeding pests. Cultural practices like crop rotation, field sanitation by removing crop residues and weeds, and deep summer ploughing help reduce root weevil populations.

Final Answer: Root weevils are soil-dwelling beetles whose larvae feed on plant roots, causing yellowing, wilting, stunted growth, and sometimes plant death due to root damage. While they are not usually a major threat to wheat, regular scouting is important to detect infestations early and distinguish them from similar pests like termites or root grubs. Chemical control includes soil drenching with Fipronil 5% SC at 500 ml per acre, which targets larvae in the soil. Seed treatment with systemic insecticides such as Imidacloprid or Thiamethoxam is recommended for early protection against root-feeding pests. Cultural practices like crop rotation, field sanitation by removing crop residues and weeds, and deep summer ploughing help reduce root weevil populations.

QueryText: Information Regarding Zink Deficiency In Wheat Crop

QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to prevent Zinc deficiency in wheat crop?

QueryText_normalized: information regarding zink deficiency in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Symptoms of zinc deficiency in wheat is Interveinal chlorosis: Yellowing between leaf veins, Stunted growth and reduced tillering, Light brown lesions with dark margins on mature leaves and Poor grain filling and lower yield use soil applications apply Zinc Sulfate @ 5-15 kg/acre at sowing, Foliar sprays like Zinc sulfate 0.5-1kg/acre in 100 L of water. Spraying can be done in the vegetative growth phase or when the deficiency symptoms begin to appear. Repeat sprays 2-3 times with a 10–14-day interval between applications.

Spraying can be done in the vegetative growth phase or when the deficiency symptoms begin to appear. Apply foliar sprays at 30-35 days after sowing and again at boot stage.

QueryText: Howto Control Of Tela In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Tela (Jassids) in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Tela in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray To Malathion 50Ec  400Ml In 200 Litres Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: howto control of tela in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Tela or jassid is a small green insect that sucks  juice from wheat leaves, causing yellowing, curling, and plant weakness. It reduces crop growth and final yield. Tela attack is more common in early sown wheat and in dry weather. To control tela, always sow recommended high yielding varieties like HD-3086, or WH-1105 which show better tolerance. Avoid too early sowing. If symptom is seen, spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 100 ml per acre or Thiamethoxam 25 WG @ 40 gram per acre in 200 litres water. Both are safe and effective. Use fan type nozzle for proper coverage. Spray early morning or late afternoon for best results. Repeat only if pest reappears. Avoid back-to-back use of same chemical to prevent resistance. Rotate with alternate groups like foliar spray Acetamiprid 20 SP @ 80 gram per in 200 litres of water for per acre if needed. Remove weeds from field as they attract tela. Follow regular crop monitoring. This low-cost spray protects wheat from damage and helps farmers to get better yield.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Of Termite In Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Termites in Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Termites in Paddy?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Of Termite In Paddybroadcast Cloropyriphos  15 Lt In 20 Kg Sand Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control of termite in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): Termites in paddy can damage the rice root and affect young seedlings, causing yellowing, wilting, and reducing tillering. To control termites in paddy, do deep ploughing and harrowing before sowing and apply chlorpyrifos 20% EC in soil @ 1l/acre, mix with 50 kg soil and spread it across the field or drench in soil during puddling. Or you can use Fipronil 0.3% GR 10 kg/acre broadcast before transplanting the paddy.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Termites in paddy can damage the rice root and affect young seedlings, causing yellowing, wilting, and reducing tillering. To control termites in paddy, do deep ploughing and harrowing before sowing, and apply chlorpyrifos 20% EC in soil @ 500/700 ml/acre mix with 50 kg soil and spread it across the field, or drench in soil just before the last puddling. Or you can use Fipronil 0.3% GR 10 kg/acre broadcast before or at transplanting the paddy in standing water.
Comment (Reviewer1):
-	Adjust the chlorpyrifos 20% EC soil application dose to 500â€“750ml per acre (not 1L), mixed thoroughly in sand or soil (preferably moist) and applied just before last puddling or at transplanting.

-	For fipronil 0.3% GR, use a dose of 10kg per acre, broadcast evenly before or at transplanting in standing water.

Or you can use Fipronil 0.3% GR 10 kg/acre broadcast before or at transplanting the paddy in standing water.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Termites in paddy can damage the rice root and affect young seedlings, causing yellowing, wilting, and reducing tillering. To control termites in paddy, do deep ploughing and harrowing before sowing.  You can use Fipronil 0.3% GR 6-10 kg/acre broadcast before or at transplanting the paddy in standing water.

Primary Answer (Level0): Termites in wheat attack roots and stems from below the soil, causing wilting and plant death in patches, especially in dry conditions. To control termites in wheat broadcast 8 kg Fipronil 00.30 GR in per acre area and after that do light irrigation.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Termites in wheat attack roots and stems from below the soil, causing wilting and plant death in patches, especially in dry conditions. Before sowing, treat the seeds with suitable insecticides like Thiamethoxam 30 FS (10 ml per kg of seed) or Imidacloprid 600 FS (1.2 ml per kg of seed). This seed treatment gives long-lasting protection right from germination and is more economical than curative sprays. To control termites in standing crop broadcast 8 kg Fipronil 00.30 GR in per acre area and after that do light irrigation.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Termite In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Termites in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Termites in Wheat Crop?
KccAns: Broadcast Of Chlorpyriphash  150 Liter 20 Kg Dry Sentacre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control termite in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Termites may attack any growth stages of the crop from seedlings to maturity. Severely damaged plants can be easily uprooted and appear wilted. To control termites, broadcast Super confider (Imidacloprid 30.5 SC) 1 liter mixed with 20 kg sand/acre or Reagent (Fipronil 5% SC) 500 ml mixed with 20 kg sand/acre or Tallstar Bifenthrin 10% EC: 400 ml mixed with 20 kg sand/acre. Apply irrigation after treatment to work the insecticide mix.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Termites are a serious pest in wheat, especially under dry soil conditions. Typical symptoms include yellowing of plants, wilting, and damage to roots and the base of the stem. Do seed treatment before sowing using Imidacloprid 600 FS @ 90 ml per 40 kg seed or Thiamethoxam 30 FS @ 10 ml per kg of seed. As a soil treatment soil drenching with Fipronil 5 SC @ 500 ml/acre or foliar spray of Lambda-cyhalothrin 5% EC @ 120 ml/acre or Bifenthrin 10% EC @ 400 ml/acre can help target adult termites, although these are generally less effective than seed treatment. Culturally, practice crop rotation with legumes, and avoid late sowing, which increases termite risk. Using resistant or tolerant varieties can also reduce losses.
Comment (Reviewer1): Missing Primary Recommendation: The biggest flaw is that it fails to mention the primary, most effective, and most economical method of termite control in wheat, which is seed treatment with a chemical like Thiamethoxam 30 FS (at 10 ml/kg seed) or Imidacloprid 48 FS (at 5 ml/kg seed) before sowing. The broadcast method is a secondary, curative measure.

QueryText: The Fertiliser Dose In Basmati
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Fertilizer dose for Basmati Paddy
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How much fertilizer is required for the Basmati crop?
KccAns: Apply To Urea -50 Kg 75 Kg Ssp 10 Kg Zinc Sulphate 10 Kg Acre
QueryText_normalized: the fertiliser dose in basmati
Primary Answer (Level0): The basal dose for basmati rice according to your region is Nitrogen is 60- 80 Kg, Phosphorus 30 Kg, and Potassium is 30 Kg per acre. To get this dose for paddy, you can use 90-100 kg urea in 2 split dosages,se first at 3 weeks after transplanting and second at 6 weeks after transplanting, 80 kg DAP at the time of transplanting, and 45 kg MOP at the time of transplanting. Split only the nitrogen dosage, and others can be applied in one go.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The recommended fertilizer dose for Basmati rice in your region during the summer season includes 60–80 kg of Nitrogen (N), 30 kg of Phosphorus (P₂O₅), and 30 kg of Potassium (K₂O) per acre. To achieve this dose, you can apply 90–120 kg of Urea per acre, split into 3 to 4 applications for better nitrogen use efficiency. The first dose of Urea should be given around 21 DAT, the second at 40 DAT, and the third at 60 DAT before panicle initiation. Phosphorus can be supplied through 40–60 kg of Di-Ammonium Phosphate (DAP) and Potassium through 45–50 kg of Muriate of Potash (MOP), both applied as a basal dose during transplanting. It is also beneficial to apply 2 tons of well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) during final land preparation to improve soil fertility and structure. A soil test is highly recommended before applying fertilizers to ensure balanced nutrition and avoid excess use, particularly of DAP, which can lead to nutrient imbalance and reduced zinc availability.
Comment (Reviewer1):
-	Clarify that the urea nitrogen dose can be split into 2â€“4 applications, with 3â€“4 splits preferred for better nitrogen use efficiency and yield in basmati rice.
Research in Haryana shows more splits of nitrogen improve uptake and reduce losses.

-	Suggest a lower DAP dose of 40â€“60kg per acre unless soil test phosphorus is low; 80kg is higher than typical state recommendations.
Overuse of DAP is common, but 40â€“60kg/acre is sufficient for most soils unless phosphorus is critically deficient.

-	Recommend conducting a soil test for phosphorus and potassium before applying final fertilizer doses.

Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Basmati rice is a Kharif crop in Haryana. It is sown with the onset of the monsoon in June-July and harvested in October-November. It is not grown as a summer crop. The recommended fertilizer dose for Basmati rice in your region during the summer season includes 24-30 kg of Nitrogen (N), 12-15 kg of Phosphorus (P₂O₅), and 12-15 kg of Potassium (K₂O) per acre. To achieve this dose, you can apply 40-50 kg of Urea per acre, split into 3 to 4 applications for better nitrogen use efficiency. It is also beneficial to apply 2 tons of well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) during final land preparation to improve soil fertility and structure. A soil test is highly recommended before applying fertilizers to ensure balanced nutrition and avoid excess use, particularly of DAP, which can lead to nutrient imbalance and reduced zinc availability.

QueryText: Nursery Sowing Time Of Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Nursery sowing time of Paddy
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: What is the nursery sowing time of paddy in Faridabad?
KccAns: 15 May -30 Jun
QueryText_normalized: nursery sowing time of paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): The correct nursery sowing time for Kharif paddy depends on the specific variety you plant. For high-yielding non-Basmati (Parmal) types like PR 126 or PR 131, the ideal window for nursery sowing is from mid-May to the first week of June. For premium Basmati varieties like the world-famous Pusa Basmati 1121 or the early-maturing Pusa Basmati 1509, you must sow the nursery later, from the first week to the third week of June. This later sowing for Basmati is critical because it allows the crop to flower in cooler weather, which is the secret to getting its famous long grain and strong aroma that fetches the highest market price.

QueryText: Time Of Ist Irrigation In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: When to do the first irrigation in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: When is the first irrigation done in the Wheat crop?
KccAns: Time Of Ist Irrigation In Wheat Crop :- After 22 Days Of Sowing Time
QueryText_normalized: time of ist irrigation in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Wheat should be preferably grown as a Rabi crop and the first irrigation is to be done immediately after sowing and the next irrigation is done after 20 days of sowing which is the time for root development and it helps in nutrient uptake.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The first irrigation irrigation schedule in wheat in Haryana conditions is conducted at 21- 25 days after sowing the crop as it coincides with the crown initiation stage in wheat. The irrigation follows  40-45 , 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115 and 125-130 days after sowing. In total 6-7 irrigations based on soil type and rainfall.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Dangerously Incorrect Advice: It states, "The first irrigation is to be done immediately after sowing." This is completely wrong for wheat in Haryana and will cause severe soil crusting, destroying germination.

Missing Correct Information: The first irrigation in wheat is always given at the critical Crown Root Initiation (CRI) stage, which occurs 21-25 days after sowing. The answer incorrectly calls this the "next irrigation."
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Wheat should be preferably grown as a Rabi crop and the first irrigation schedule in wheat The irrigation follows  40-45 , 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115 and 125-130 days after sowing. In total 6-7 irrigations based on soil type and rainfall.
Comment (Reviewer2): Irrigation schedule depends on soil; 6–7 irrigations is for medium soil — sandy soils may need more.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): Wheat should be preferably grown as a Rabi crop and the first irrigation schedule in wheat  is conducted at 21- 25 days after sowing the crop, as it coincides with the crown initiation stage in wheat. The irrigation follows  40-45, 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115 and 125-130 days after sowing. In total, 6-7 irrigations based on soil type and rainfall.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3): Wheat should preferably be grown as a Rabi crop, and the first irrigation schedule in wheat is conducted at 21- 25 days after sowing the crop, as it coincides with the crown initiation stage in wheat. The irrigation follows  40-45, 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115, and 125-130 days after sowing. In total, 6-7 irrigations are based on soil type and rainfall.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4): Wheat should preferably be grown as a Rabi crop, and the first irrigation schedule in wheat is conducted at 21- 25 days after sowing the crop, as it coincides with the crown initiation stage in wheat. The irrigation follows  40-45, 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115, and 125-130 days after sowing. In total, 6-7 irrigations are based on soil type and rainfall.
Final Answer: Wheat should preferably be grown as a Rabi crop, and the first irrigation schedule in wheat is conducted at 21- 25 days after sowing the crop, as it coincides with the crown initiation stage in wheat. The irrigation follows  40-45, 60-65, 80-85, 95-100, 110-115, and 125-130 days after sowing. In total, 6-7 irrigations are based on soil type and rainfall.

QueryText: How To Control Of Flower Droping In Cotton
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control flower dropping in Cotton?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control flower dropping In Cotton?
KccAns: Spray Of Pilanofix 1Ml In 45Lt Water
QueryText_normalized: how to control of flower droping in cotton
Primary Answer (Level0): The primary causes of flower dropping in cotton is due to heat stress, moisture stress, nutrient imbalance and insect pet pressure like aphids and thrips. To control the flower drops in cotton ensure proper soil moisture at the time of flowering, always give balance nutrients, spray boron 1g/litre of water at the time of flowering repeat spray at 15 days intervals or you can use growth regulators  like Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 1 ml/ litre of water at the time of 50 % flowering, spray in evening for best results. Monitor for pests and insects regularly and take corrective measures accordingly.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The primary causes of flower dropping in cotton are due to heat stress, moisture stress, nutrient imbalance, a nd insect pest pressure, like aphids and thrips. To control the flower drops in cotton ensure proper soil moisture at the time of flowering, always give balance nutrients, spray boron 1g/litre of water at the time of flowering repeat spray at 15 days intervals or you can use growth regulators like Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA) @ 40-45 ml/acre at the time of 50 % flowering, spray in evening for best results. Monitor for pests and insects regularly and take corrective measures accordingly. Excessive use of NAA or boron, or tank-mixing without compatibility checks, can reduce flowering or cause crop injury.

- Reduce boron spray dose to 1g per litre of water, not more. Standard regional advice is 1g/L or 150â€“200g/acre per spray; higher rates risk toxicity and do not improve results.

- For Naphthalene Acetic Acid (NAA), specify the dose as 4â€“5ml of 4.5% SL per 15L pump or 40â€“45ml per acre (equates to about 0.3â€“0.5ml/L depending on formulation).
Manufacturer and regional guidelines suggest about 4â€“5ml per 15L or 1ml/L for correct effect and crop safety.

- Clearly mention that excessive use of NAA or boron, or tank-mixing without compatibility checks, can reduce flowering or cause crop injury.

QueryText: Information Regarding Seed Treament Of Wheat
Refined KCC Query [HF]: Information regarding the seed treatment of Wheat
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: Information regarding the seed treatment of Wheat?
KccAns: Seed Treament Of Wheat Are:- Bavistin2Gram In 1Kg Seeds
QueryText_normalized: information regarding seed treament of wheat
Primary Answer (Level0): There is no seed treatment recommended for wheat in the Kharif season because wheat is not grown in Kharif  but in rabi season we can treat the seeds with fungicides(Loose smut, false smut) - treating wheat seeds with Carbendazim (2g/kg of seed), Thiram(1.5 to 1.87 g/kg of seed), and Tebuconazole(1.5 to 1.87g/kg of seed). Insecticides (Termites)- Chlorpyriphos @ 4 ml/kg seed.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): There is no seed treatment recommended for wheat is not grown in Kharif in Hisar or anywhere in Haryana but in rabi season we can treat the seeds with fungicides(Loose smut, false smut) - treating wheat seeds with Carbendazim (2g/kg of seed), Thiram(1.5 to 1.87 g per kg of seed), and Tebuconazole(1.5 to 1.87g per kg of seed). Insecticides (Termites)- Chlorpyriphos @ 4 ml/kg seed.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Convert “g/kg seed” to “g per 5 kg seed (approx. per acre requirement).
Farmers measure seed treatment per batch; 5 kg of seed roughly covers one acre.

- Clarify no Kharif cultivation
Rephrase to: “Wheat is not sown in Kharif in Haryana; for Rabi, treat seed with Carbendazim 2 g, Thiram 1.5 g or Tebuconazole 1.5 g per 5 kg seed.”
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): There is no seed treatment recommended for wheat is not grown in Kharif but in rabi season we can treat the seeds with fungicides(Loose smut, false smut) - treating wheat seeds with Carbendazim (2g/kg of seed), Thiram(1.5 to 1.87 g per kg of seed), and Tebuconazole(1.5 to 1.87g per kg of seed). Insecticides (Termites)- Chlorpyriphos @ 4 ml/kg seed.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Thiram dose should be 2.5 g/kg, not “1.5 to 1.87 g”.

Chlorpyriphos seed treatment not recommended in food crops; use fipronil instead for termites.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2): There is no seed treatment recommended for wheat grown in the Kharif season, as wheat is primarily a Rabi crop. In the Rabi season, seeds can be treated with fungicides to protect against diseases like loose smut and false smut: Carbendazim – 2 g per kg of seed, Thiram – 2.5 g per kg of seed, Tebuconazole – 1.5–1.87 g per kg of seed For insect protection (e.g., termites), seeds can be treated with: Fipronil – 0.3 g per kg of seed.
Comment (Reviewer3): "There is no seed treatment recommended for wheat grown in the Kharif season"—which can be misleading or too rigid. Better rephare the initial sentence to "Wheat is primarily a Rabi season crop in India, and seed treatment recommendations predominantly apply to Rabi wheat. Since wheat is rarely cultivated in the Kharif season, there are generally no standard seed treatment practices for Kharif-grown wheat". Seed treatment dosage for Fipronil should be stated as 0.3 g a.i./kg seed (which matches approximately 0.6 ml of 5 FS formulation/kg seed) for clarity.

For insect protection (e.g., termites), seeds can be treated with: Fipronil – 0.3 g per kg of seed.

QueryText: How To Control Of Thrips In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Thrips in Cotton crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Thrips in Cotton crop?
KccAns: Spray To Rogor  350Ml In 150 Litres Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: how to control of thrips in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Thrips cause leaf curling and poor plant growth in cotton crops, so early detection and control measure is necessary. To control thrips in cotton, avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizer, regularly remove weeds in and around the cotton fields, install yellow sticky traps (6-8 per acre), and apply neem oil @ 2-3 ml per litre of water. If the infestation is high rotate insecticide spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 60 ml per acre diluted in 200 litres of water or Spinosad 45 SC @80 ml per acre mixed in 200 litres of water to prevents thrips resistance.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): The Zaid season (summer) is unsuitable for cotton cultivation in Haryana due to high heat, short duration, and lack of moisture. Cotton is mainly grown in Haryana as a Kharif crop (June-July). Thrips cause leaf curling and poor plant growth in cotton crops, and they are active during the early seedling stage (first 30-45 days after sowing), so early detection and control measures are necessary. To control thrips in cotton, avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizer, regularly remove weeds in and around the cotton fields, install yellow sticky traps (6-8 per acre), and apply neem oil at 2-3 ml per litre of water. If the infestation is high, rotate insecticide spray of Imidacloprid 17.8 SL at 60 ml per acre diluted in 200 litres of water, or Spinosad 45 SC @ 80 ml per acre mixed in 200 litres, or Fipronil 5% SC @ 400-500 ml per acre in 200 litres of water to prevent thrips resistance.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Missing Context: It fails to specify that Cotton is a Kharif crop and that Thrips are most damaging in the early seedling stage (first 30-45 days), which is the most critical window for control.

Sub-optimal Chemical Choice: While Spinosad works, a more common and highly effective recommendation for severe thrips in cotton would be Fipronil 5% SC at 400-500 ml per acre as part of the rotation.

QueryText: Information Regarding Control Of Thripsaphid In Wheat Crop-
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Thrips and Aphids in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Thrips and Aphids in Wheat crop?
KccAns: Information Regarding Control Of Thripsaphid In Wheat Crop-Spray Confidor  100 Ml In 150 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding control of thripsaphid in wheat crop-
Primary Answer (Level0): Thrips in wheat feed on leaves and tender spikes, causing silvering, curling, and reduced grain formation. To control thrips in wheat place 4-10 blue sticky traps of size 15 X 7.5 cm in per acre. For biological control spray Neem oil 10,000 ppm (5ml/l). If the thrips attack cannot be controlled biologically then only spray Thiamethoxam 25 % WG (20-40 g/acre).
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Aphids in wheat suck plant sap, leading to yellowing, curling of leaves, and reduced grain formation. To biologically control the aphids you can spray Neem oil 10,000 ppm (5ml/l) but if the pest attack is very severe then spray Imidacloprid 17.8 SL (60-80 ml/l) OR Thiamethoxam 25 WG (40-80 g/acre). After doing spray of any chemical pesticide kindly wait for 7-10 days before harvesting so that it becomes safe for consumption.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Ignores the Main Pest: The query "Thripsaphid" is a confused term, but it strongly implies the user is asking about Aphids, which are a far more common and economically damaging pest in wheat in Haryana than thrips. The answer completely ignores aphids, failing to address the farmer's primary problem.

Missing Strategic Timing (ETL): The most crucial advice for sucking pests like aphids in wheat is to spray only when the population reaches the Economic Threshold Level (ETL). An expert must state that spraying is only recommended when there are an average of 5-10 aphids per earhead, to avoid wasting money on unnecessary applications.

After doing spray of any chemical pesticide kindly wait for 7-10 days before harvesting so that it becomes safe for consumption.
Comment (Reviewer2): "Imidacloprid 17.8 SL (60–80 ml/l)" → Extremely high. Should be 60–80 ml per acre, not per litre!

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Bandar Panja In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control bandar panja in Cotton crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Bandar Panja (crazy top disease) In Cotton Crop?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Bandar Panja In Cotton Crop Spray Urea  25 Kgzinc  500 Gm In 150 Litre Of Wateracre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control bandar panja in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): Bandar panja also knowns as "Crazy top" in cotton is a physiological disorder caused by herbicide injury especially from accidental drift or contact of 2,4-D or other broadleaf weed killers. It show stunted, bushy, or distorted tops with upright branches and reduce boll set. To manage this, avoid applying 2,4-D near cotton field, apply pre emergence herbicide like Pendimethalin at strictly recommended dose immediately after sowing followed by light irrigation. If damage occurs irrigate the crop immediately and spray 2% urea solution(20 gram urea per litre of water) or 5 ml seaweed extract per litre of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Cotton is a Kharif crop in Haryana. To control Alternaria leaf spot in cotton, follow these measures: Symptoms Small, circular to irregular, dark brown to black lesions on leaves, Lesions enlarge, merge, and cause large necrotic patches and severely infected leaves turn yellow, dry, and fall prematurely Cultural Practices- Use resistant varieties like H 1117 or H 1226, Practice crop rotation, Remove and destroy infected crop debris. Biological Control- Apply Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 0.5% at 15-day intervals at early disease appearance. Chemical Control- Mancozeb 75% WP @ 2.5 g/litre water (600–1000 g per acre), Chlorothalonil 75% WP @ 2 g/litre water, Propiconazole 25% EC @ 1 ml/litre water (250 ml per acre).

QueryText: Control Of Weeds Broad Leaf Wild Oats  In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Broadleaf weeds and Wild Oats in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control wild oats weeds in Wheat?
KccAns: Spray Of Total  160Gm In 200 Litres Of Water  Acre
QueryText_normalized: control of weeds broad leaf wild oats in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): To control Broadleaf weeds use 2,4-D Sodium Salt 80% WP 250 gram in 250 liters for 30 days after sowing and for controlling wild oats use Clodinafop-propargyl 15% WP 160 gram in 150 liters for an acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
For controlling broad leaf weeds and wild oats in Wheat it is essential to apply pre-emergence herbicide within 1-2 days after sowing and before crop emergence . The best suited weedicide will  be Pendimethalin + Metribuzin  (CS formulation) 1.2 liters of it is mixed in 250 liters of water.

After the growth of weeds , a combination chemical of Clodinafop Propargyl 15% + Metsulfuron Methyl 1% WP prepared by mixing 400 gram in 375 liter of water . The ideal timing for application is 35 days after sowing. A waiting period of 100 days is suggested between last spray and harvest to avoid contamination by the chemical.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Impractical Recommendation: A farmer with both broadleaf and grassy weeds (like wild oats) needs a more efficient solution. The best advice is to recommend a ready-mix herbicide that controls both types in a single spray, such as Sulfosulfuron + Metsulfuron-methyl, instead of two separate spray operations.

Vague Timing: It gives a timing for the 2,4-D spray but not for the Clodinafop. A clear, consistent timing should be given for all post-emergence sprays, which is 30-35 days after sowing.

After the growth of weeds , a combination chemical of Clodinafop Propargyl 15% + Metsulfuron Methyl 1% WP prepared by mixing 400 gram in 375 liter of water . The ideal timing for application is 35 days after sowing. A waiting period of 100 days is suggested between last spray and harvest to avoid contamination by the chemical.
Comment (Reviewer2): Waiting period “100 days” after post-emergence is excessive; actual PHI for Clodinafop + Metsulfuron is ~30 days.

Primary Answer (Level0): To control nematodes in wheat can be a serious problem for wheat cultivation. causing stunted growth, reduced tillering, and lower yields Use Cultural control like crop rotation, deep summer ploughing, biological control like use resistant varieties (Raj MR-1), treat the seeds with Carbofuran 3G or Fipronil 5% SC @ 5 ml/kg seed or Tebuconazole + Trifloxystrobin (Fungicide combo) @ 1.5-2 g/kg seed it Helps control seed-borne pathogens and early root nematode attacks, apply organic neem cake or mustard cake to suppresses nematode multiplication.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): To control nematodes in wheat can be a serious problem for wheat cultivation in Haryana, causing stunted growth, reduced tillering, and lower yields Use Cultural control like crop rotation, deep summer ploughing, biological control like use resistant varieties (Raj MR-1),  neem or mustard cake @ 250kg/acre Seed-dress with Fipronil 5% SC @ 5 ml/kg seed , apply organic neem cake or mustard cake to suppresses nematode multiplication.

Remove the banned chemical Carbofuran
– Delete “treat the seeds with Carbofuran 3G.”

- Recommend permitted alternatives

Fipronil is registered; Tebuconazole + Trifloxystrobin addresses fungal pathogens but does not control nematodes, so omit as a nematicide.

Emphasize cultural and organic methods first
– Preface: “Use crop rotation, deep summer ploughing, resistant variety Raj MR-1, neem or mustard cake @ 250 kg/acre.”
Because - Integrated nematode management prioritizes non‐chemical controls.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Root Rot In Paddy
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Root rot in Paddy?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control root rot in Paddy?
KccAns: Spray 250 Gm Carbendazim In 120 Lt Of Water Per Acre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control root rot in paddy
Primary Answer (Level0): To control Root rot  in paddy mix trichoderma harzianum or pseudomonas flourescenes @ 2.5 kg acre with FYM as in soil application or drench fermented buttermilk 10% + asafoetida. Or you can use Carbendazim 50% WP or hexaconazole 5% SC @ 2 g/ litre of water.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Root rot is a serious fungal disease in paddy caused by pathogens. It usually attacks when there is poor drainage, excessive water stagnation, or a nutrient imbalance. To control Root rot in paddy mix Trichoderma harzianum or Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 2.5 kg acre with FYM as in soil application or drench fermented buttermilk 10% + asafoetida. Or you can use Carbendazim 50% WP @ 1 g/litre or hexaconazole 5% SC @ 1 ml/ litre of water. Avoid simultaneous use of chemical fungicides and biocontrol (Trichoderma/Pseudomonas). Combining them reduces the efficacy of bioagents. Keep at least 4 to 5days's gap between applications if both are needed.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Reduce or clarify chemical fungicide doses: For Carbendazim 50% WP, use 1g per litre of water (not 2g); for Hexaconazole 5% SC, use 1ml per litre (not 2g, as SC is in ml, not g).
Standard regional doses for paddy root rot are 1g/L for Carbendazim WP and 1ml/L for Hexaconazole SC; higher or mixed units can confuse farmers and increase residue risk.

- Avoid simultaneous use of chemical fungicides and biocontrol (Trichoderma/pseudomonas):
Combining them reduces efficacy of bioagents; regionally advised to keep at least 4â€“5 days gap between applications if both are needed

QueryText: The Control Of Rice Root Weevil In Paddy Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Rice Root Weevil in Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Root Weevil in Paddy crop?
KccAns: Apply To Foret 10-G  4 Kg In Mixed Urea  Acre
QueryText_normalized: the control of rice root weevil in paddy crop
Primary Answer (Level0): To control root weevil in paddy apply Neem cake 250kg/acre during puddling before transplanting. Before transplanting dip root in imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 5ml/L water for 20 minutes or you can spray at the base of crop Fipronil 5% SC @ 1.5ml/litre of water in evening because weevil is active at night, or give soil drenching of Thiamethoxam 30% FS 50 ml/acre in 200 litre of water at 20 DAT. Plant sorghum as a trap crop.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): Root weevil can damage the roots of rice, especially in young plants, leading to stunted growth, yellowing, and wilting. To control root weevil in paddy, apply Neem cake 250kg/acre during puddling before transplanting (though some references recommend up to 400 to 600kg/acre for maximum effect. Before transplanting dip root in imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 5ml/L water for 20 minutes, or you can spray at the base of the crop Fipronil 5% SC @ 1.5ml/litre of water in evening because weevil is active at night, or give soil drenching of Thiamethoxam 30% FS 50 ml/acre in 200 litre of water at 20 DAT. Planting sorghum as a trap crop is an integrated Pest Management (IPM) practice for paddy in Haryana.
Comment (Reviewer1):
-	Neem cake dose of 250kg per acre is acceptable, though some references recommend up to 400â€“600kg/acre for maximum effect; your dose is within safe and effective regional practice.

-	Mentioning sorghum as a trap crop is a validated integrated pest management (IPM) practice for paddy in Haryana.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): Root weevil can damage the roots of rice, especially in young plants, leading to stunted growth, yellowing, and wilting. To control root weevil in paddy, apply Neem cake 250kg/acre during puddling before transplanting (though some references recommend up to 400 to 600kg/acre for maximum effect. Before transplanting dip root in imidacloprid 17.8 SL @ 5ml/L water for 20 minutes, or you can spray at the base of the crop Fipronil 5% SC @ 1.5ml/litre of water in evening because weevil is active at night, or give soil drenching of Thiamethoxam 30% FS 50 ml/acre in 200 litre of water at 20 DAT. Planting sorghum as a trap crop is an integrated Pest Management (IPM) practice for paddy in Haryana.

QueryText: How To Control Of Tella In Paddy Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Tela (Jassids) in Paddy crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Tela (Brown plant Hoppers) in Paddy Crop?
KccAns: Spray To Endosalfan-35Ec 350 Ml In 200 Litre Of Water Acre In Paddy Crop
QueryText_normalized: how to control of tella in paddy crop
Primary Answer (Level0): To control Tella in paddy crop Tella is usually called as Brown planthopper (BPH) These pests suck sap from the plant base, cause yellowing or wilting, and transmit viral diseases like tungro. Symptoms are Hopper burn: Plants dry from base, Honeydew secretion, sooty mold on leaves. There is a cultural control like Remove and destroy infested tillers or plants early. Avoid excess nitrogen fertilizers. Mechanical control like use light traps or yellow sticky traps. Chemical control like Spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL -100 ml/acre in 200 L water, Buprofezin 25% SC - 400–500 ml/acre in 200 L of water, and Thiamethoxam 25% WG -(100 g/acre) in 200 L of water to control BPH in paddy.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): To control Tella in paddy crop Tella is usually called as Brown planthopper (BPH) These pests suck sap from the plant base, cause yellowing or wilting, and transmit viral diseases like tungro. Symptoms are Hopper burn: Plants dry from base, Honeydew secretion, sooty mold on leaves. There is a cultural control like Remove and destroy infested tillers or plants early. Avoid excess nitrogen fertilizers. Mechanical control like use light traps or yellow sticky traps. Chemical control like Spray Imidacloprid 17.8% SL -100 ml/acre in 200 L water, Buprofezin 25% SC - 400–500 ml/acre in 200 L of water, and Thiamethoxam 25% WG -(20 g/acre) in 200 L of water to control BPH in paddy.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Paddy (Rice) is a primary Kharif crop in Haryana, grown during the monsoon season. The recommendation must be for the Kharif season.   
- The standard recommendation for Thiamethoxam for Brown Plant Hopper (BPH) is 50g/ha, which translates to approximately 20 g/acre. The suggested 100 g/acre is a five-fold overdose that could harm the crop and the environment.
- The answer lists multiple chemicals without instructing the farmer to use only one. It also lacks a recommended water volume.
The answer must be rephrased to state that any one of the insecticides should be used to avoid improper mixing. Furthermore, a standard water volume (e.g., 200 litres per acre) must be specified to ensure correct spray concentration.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1): To control Tella in paddy crop Tella is usually called as Brown planthopper (BPH) These pests suck sap from the plant base, cause yellowing or wilting, and transmit viral diseases like tungro. Symptoms are Hopper burn: Plants dry from base, Honeydew secretion, sooty mold on leaves. There is a cultural control like Remove and destroy infested tillers or plants early. QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Termit In Cotton Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Termites in Cotton crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How To Control Termites In Cotton Crop?
KccAns: Information Regarding How To Control Termit In Cotton Crop Broadcast Chlorpyriphos  15 Litre In 25 Kg Dry Sendacre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control termit in cotton crop
Primary Answer (Level0): To control Termite in Cotton during the early stages it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil 5 ml in 1 liter of water and spread it around each plant.If the attack continues make sure to spray Chlorpyrifos 20 EC 2-3 ml in 1 liter of water and drench the soil surrounding the plant with half the water. If Chlorpyrifos is not available you can use Fipronil 5% 2 ml in 1 liter and drench the soil. Make sure to do seed treatment wilth Chlorpyriphos and basal application of soil with neem oil.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0):
To control termite attack in cotton it is essential to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed. 
To control Termite in Cotton during the early stages it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil 40 ml in 200 liters of water and sprayed in initial stages,
If the attack continues make sure to spray Chlorpyrifos 20 EC 300 ml in 150 liters of water. If Chlorpyrifos is not available you can use Fipronil 5% prepared by mixing 300 ml in 150 liters of water.
Comment (Reviewer1):
Impractical Dosages: It gives all chemical doses per litre, which is not practical for a field-scale soil drench. The answer must provide the standard per-acre rate (e.g., Chlorpyrifos 20% EC at 1-1.5 litres per acre).

Vague Seed Treatment Advice: It just says seed treatment "wilth Chlorpyriphos." A specific recommendation is needed, and a more modern choice for termites and sucking pests is Imidacloprid 48% FS at 5-7 ml per kg of seed.
Updated with Reviewer1 (Level 1):
To control termite attack in cotton it is essential to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed. 
To control Termite in Cotton during the early stages it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil 40 ml in 200 liters of water and sprayed in initial stages,
If the attack continues make sure to spray Chlorpyrifos 20 EC 300 ml in 150 liters of water. If Chlorpyrifos is not available you can use Fipronil 5% prepared by mixing 300 ml in 150 liters of water.
Comment (Reviewer2):
Seed treatment: Imidacloprid 600 FS dose should be 5 ml/kg for 48% formulation; confirm formulation before prescribing.

Neem oil drench is not a strong preventive; only supportive.
Updated with Reviewer2 (Level 2):
To control termite attack in cotton, it is essential to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed. To control termites in Cotton during the early stages, it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil, 40 ml in 200 litres of water, and spray in the initial stages.
If the attack continues, make sure to spray Fipronil 5% prepared by mixing 300 ml in 150 litres of water. Ensure to follow a pre-harvest interval of 30 days to avoid contamination.
Updated with Reviewer3 (Level 3):
To control termite attack in cotton, it is essential to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed. To control termites in Cotton during the early stages, it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil, 40 ml in 200 litres of water, and spray in the initial stages.
If the attack continues, make sure to spray Fipronil 5% prepared by mixing 300 ml in 150 litres of water. Ensure to follow a pre-harvest interval of 30 days to avoid contamination.
Comment (Reviewer4): The advice to drench the soil with neem oil for termite control is highly misleading and ineffective for large-scale infestations. While neem oil has some insecticidal properties and can act as a repellent, it is not a primary or reliable method for controlling a severe termite attack in a field setting.  Its use is more suitable for very minor, localized infestations or as a preventative measure in a home garden, not in a commercial cotton field. You can add cultural practices such as deep summer plowing, removing old crop residues and stubble, and using well-decomposed Farm Yard Manure (FYM) to reduce termite populations and habitats.                                                                                                                                                  Fipronil 5% SC is most effective against termites when it is applied to the soil, not as a foliar spray on the leaves. The text suggests a "spray" application, which would be ineffective against a root-feeding pest. The correct method for Fipronil is a soil drench at the base of the plant or a granular broadcast application followed by light irrigation. Also dose seems quite low, please check the dose again.
Updated with Reviewer4 (Level 4):
To control Termites during the initial stages integrate cultural practices such as deep summer ploughing, removal of crop residues and stubble, and application of only well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) to reduce termite populations. Along with this, it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil, 40 ml in 200 litres of water, and spray in the initial stages. 

Next measure is to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed.

In case of severe infestations, Fipronil 5% EC 300 ml in 200 liters of water as soil drench should be applied to reduce the infestation. Maintain a minimum of 30 days between application and cotton harvest to avoid residue issues and contamination.
Final Answer:
To control Termites during the initial stages, integrate cultural practices such as deep summer ploughing, removal of crop residues and stubble, and application of only well-decomposed farmyard manure (FYM) to reduce termite populations. Along with this, it is essential to drench the soil with neem oil, 40 ml in 200 litres of water, and spray in the initial stages. 

The next measure is to do seed treatment with Imidacloprid 600 FS 5 ml/kg of seed.

In case of severe infestations, Fipronil 5% EC 300 ml in 200 liters of water as a soil drench should be applied to reduce the infestation. Maintain a minimum of 30 days between application and cotton harvest to avoid residue issues and contamination.

QueryText: Information Regarding How To Control Termit In Wheat Crop
Refined KCC Query [HF]: How to control Termites in Wheat crop?
QUESTION [by Agri Team]: How to control Termites in Wheat Crops?
KccAns: Broadcast Chlorpyriphos  15 Litre In 25 Kg Dry Sendacre
QueryText_normalized: information regarding how to control termit in wheat crop
Primary Answer (Level0): To control termites in wheat crop during the Kharif season in Sirsa, an integrated approach is essential for especially because termites are soil-borne pests that attack seeds, roots, and stems, leading to poor germination, plant wilting, and crop failure, While wheat is primarily grown in Rabi season, if being cultivated in Kharif termite pressure can increase due to higher soil moisture and organic matter from monsoon Mix granular insecticides evenly in soil during the last ploughing or just before sowing, Avoid leaving uncomposed organic matter, as it attracts termites. spray Chlorpyrifos 20% EC- 1 l/acre, Fipronil 0.3% GR-4kg/acre and Imidacloprid 30.5% SC- 240ml/acre.
Initial Moderated Answer (Level 0): To control termites in wheat crop during the Kharif season in Sirsa, an integrated approach is essential for especially because termites are soil-borne pests that attack seeds, roots, and stems, leading to poor germination, plant wilting, and crop failure, While wheat is primarily grown in Rabi season, if being cultivated in Kharif termite pressure can increase due to higher soil moisture and organic matter from monsoon Mix granular insecticides evenly in soil during the last ploughing or just before sowing, Avoid leaving uncomposed organic matter, as it attracts termites. spray soil-applied granular is Cartap hydrochloride 4% GR at 10 kg/acre. and Chlorantraniliprole 0.4% GR at 8 kg/acre during the last ploughing.
Comment (Reviewer1):
- Chlorpyrifos 20% EC and Fipronil formulations are banned for in-furrow or soil applications in Haryana; the permitted soil-applied granular is Cartap hydrochloride 4% GR at 10 kg/acre.

- Imidacloprid 30.5% SC is not labelled for termite control; replace with Chlorantraniliprole 0.4% GR at 8 kg/acre during the last ploughing.

Haryana State Insecticide Act prohibits certain soil insecticides; use locally approved actives for subterranean termites.
